Fixes #2052 

What changes did you make and why?

Consolidated permission checks using dexter

title: Nothing happens after granting storage permissions while making gallery uploads
body:
**Summary:** 

Nothing happens after granting storage permissions while making gallery uploads

**Steps to reproduce:** 

- Frest install 2.9.0
- Click on gallery fab icon
- grant permissions

Nothing happens. Expected behaviour is that gallery will open

**Device and Android version:** 

 API level >= 23

**Commons app version:** 

2.9.0

**Would you like to work on the issue?**

Yes

title: Search this area
body:
**Description (required)**

Fixes #591 "Search this area" to launch a nearby search around that location

What changes did you make and why?
- When you moved on the map a button "Search this area" appears on top of the map
- If you don't click on the button, and come back your previous position, button disappears
- If you click to the button, a progress bar will appear on the map, and map will be locked, you can not move on the map during fetching places
- Only your location marker and your new search results will be visible on map and list
- If you move, map won't follow you if search this area mode on
- If you click to extend list, map camera won't change its target
- When you click on recenter me button, or go back to previous position on map with your fingers, nearby places around you will be uploaded
- Map will follow you as always
- Extending list will change map camera angle, so that your location will still be visible

**Tests performed (required)**
Tested betaDebug, on API19 and 26
**Screenshots showing what changed (optional - for UI changes)**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3127881/49241407-ccf80980-f418-11e8-991d-4113d629fca9.png)

title: Bug fix issue #2042 (Blank Achievements Activity)
body:
**Description (required)**
When the api call to fetch the achievements somehow fails, a blank screen shows up and user is left with no option to retry.
Fixes #2042 Achievements is blank for some users.

What changes did you make and why?
* Added a sticky snack bar in achievements activity which shows up when fetch api fails
* Snackbar comes with an action button which on click retries fetch. This way user is never shown a blank screen and always has an option to retry fetches

**Tests performed (required)**

Tested {build variant, ProdDebug} on {One Plus 3T} with API level {27}.

**Screenshots showing what changed (optional - for UI changes)**
![device-2018-11-29-230404](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17375274/49240730-f2424300-f42b-11e8-9d86-e4a343c8a752.png)

title: Multiple dialog are generating on Nearby page when user has explicitly denied location permission to app through system.
body:
**Summary:** 
Multiple dialog are generating on Nearby page when user has explicitly denied location permission to app through system. 
Expected : If nearby page could not be opened without location permission, we can show one time dialog and show home screen.

**Steps to reproduce:** 
1. Open Nearby Places and allow location permission.
2. Go to system and revoke app's location permission.
3. Now whenever you open Nearby Places, dialog keeps on generating for long time.

App should show one time dialog and show last accessed page.


**System logs:**

NA

**Device and Android version:** 

Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge.
Android Version 7.0 Nougat.

 
**Commons app version:** 
App Version - 2.8.5


**Screen-shots:** 
![screenshot_20181129-223454](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15213376/49239354-9629ef80-f428-11e8-9605-81711396b850.png)


**Would you like to work on the issue?**

Sure

title: 2.9.0: Unable to exit app after going to notifications activity
body:
**Summary:**
I am unable to exit the app using the back button just after I go to the notifications activity. Hitting the back button cycles through the notification and main screen infinitely.

**Steps to reproduce:** 
1. Open the app
2. Tap on the notification icon (left end of the top bar)
3. Hit back (should have come to the main screen)
4. Hit back to exit the app
5. Hit back agian

**Observation**
When I hit back in steps 4 I am taken back to the notification activity. In step  5, I'm taken back to home screen. This goes on infinitely and I'm unable to exit the app. This seems very odd.

**Device and Android version:** 
Galaxy J1 ace running Android 5.1.1 (stock)

**Commons app version:** 
2.9.0

**Would you like to work on the issue?**
No

title: Remove Notifications and Nearby from hamburger menu
label: [Label(name="discussion")]
body:
**Summary:** 

Notifications and Nearby options in hamburger menu now feel redundant. After the recent UI overhaul, - we have notification bell icon aptly placed on the home screen. 
- we have nearby functionality(map and list) as a tab on home screen. 

Do we still need these options in the hamburger menu? If we remove these options, then the menu would look a lot simpler and will also give an option to add other items in the future.

Fixes #2029 NPE after tapping image in Explore

Initialise MediaDetailProvider based on its type as in activity or fragment

title: Add "use previous title/desc" option to new upload screen (2.9)
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body: The new upload process (2.9) is missing the "use previous title/desc" option. We would also need to discuss where in the UI it would fit best, and what sort of UI element to use.

title: Tapping the "nearest place" card view on the main screen in 2.9 should bring user to Nearby map with that particular pin selected
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
We did not have the time to implement this in #725 , but this would be a pretty useful enhancement. Currently, when the user taps the "nearest place" card view on the main screen, they are just brought to Nearby in general. They should instead be brought to Nearby with that particular pin on the map selected.

You would need to build on the 2.9-release branch.

title: Add missing lost dependency
body:
As this post(https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-native/issues/10484#issuecomment-345319647) said, lost is not included in Mapbox android SDK from version 5.2.0. This patch added explicit dependency to lost. This fixes build error "Failed to find byte code for com/mapzen/android/lost/api/LostApiClient$ConnectionCallbacks".

**Description (required)**

Fixes #2027

**Tests performed (required)**

Tested BetaDebug on Pixel 2 XL with API level 28.

title: Fix missing lost build error

Clone and build this project in Android Studio 3.2.1.
Build failed and error message is: Failed to find byte code for com/mapzen/android/lost/api/LostApiClient$ConnectionCallbacks

Yes. A pull request will be made to address this issue.

title: Keypad needs to be invisible in final step of upload screen (2.9-release branch)
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
**Summary:** 

In the 2.9-release branch, when uploading, the keypad always blocks the lower half of the screen in the final step. This is both unnecessary (there is nothing that needs typing in the final step), and bad for user experience (it blocks "Submit", so the user has to press the back button to get out of the keypad in order to submit their upload, and in the worst case scenario they may not realize that and would wonder 'why can't I complete my upload?')

**Steps to reproduce:** 

Build 2.9-release branch, upload a pic, get to final step and try to Submit

**Device and Android version:** 

Samsung Galaxy s7 API 26
 
**Commons app version:** 

2.9-release branch

**Would you like to work on the issue?**

Pref not

Nearby card notification is only visible if closest nearby item is loaded successfully. 

**Tests performed (required)**

Tested on API 26, prodDebug and betaDebug.

title: Add custom place to Nearby
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
Sometimes I hear about an interesting non-famous place on the local news.
Because it is very local, this place has no Commons picture and of course no Wikidata item.
But still, I would like to have a way to remember it in the future.

Nearby seems like a good place to put such information. I should be able to long-press anywhere on the map and add the new point's label.

There are many ways to implement backend storage:
- Locally in the app's database. Easy, but points get lost at each reinstall
- On the SD card on the phone. A bit awkward and lost when people change phones.
- As a list in a sub-page of the user. In such case we should be clear that these points are publicly visible and linked to the user.
- As a global list shared by all users of the app. Same warning as above.

In any case, loading should happen in parallel with Wikidata SPARQL loading, and points should start showing up as soon as the first points start arriving.

Low priority.

title: 'i' icon in 2.9-release branch has too wide a range
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="pre-release")]
body:
**Summary:** 

On the 2.9-release branch with the new upload UI, I wanted to remove a word from the end of my description. However, there was no way I could select the end of the sentence because whenever I tapped in an area remotely near the 'i' icon, it would trigger the tooltip instead.

**Steps to reproduce:** 

Upload picture, tap near 'i' icon (but not directly on it).

**Device and Android version:** 

Samsung Galaxy s7 running API 26
 
**Commons app version:** 

2.9-release branch

**Would you like to work on the issue?**

@maskaravivek Do you think you could fix this before 2.9? Would just need to reduce the area of the tooltip.

title: Bugfix/nearbby zoomin
body:
**Description (required)**
Nearby is currently zoomed out to a level where the user has to zoom in every time he uses nearby. Whenever the user starts Nearby, the map should be zoomed in to a reasonable distance(which is mapped to zoom level)
Fixes #1987 { Start Nearby map zoomed in }
What changes did you make and why?
Increased the zoom level to 12 which was 11 before
**Tests performed (required)**
Tested {build variant,  ProdDebug} on {One Plus 1} with API level {26}.
* Nearby zoom was appropriate (the markers were being shown properly[not too dense])
* Opening/Closing the bottom sheet no more hinders the zoom level of the map

title: Add option in Explore for users to easily browse images uploaded via our app
label: [Label(name="explore")]
body:
Users can technically already do this, but it is a bit convoluted: Directly from within the app: Tap "Explore", search for "Uploaded with Mobile/Android", tap "Categories", tap "Uploaded with Mobile/Android".

I was wondering if we should make it easier for users to browse the ones uploaded from our app (which could potentially tie into the "patrolling other images uploaded via the app" feature, finally allowing us to include that into master with a polished UI). Maybe we could have 2 tabs in the main Explore view - 1 for "Featured" (the current implementation) and 1 for "Uploaded via app"? @nicolas-raoul

title: Allow users to send Thanks for other photos in Explore
label: [Label(name="explore"), Label(name="hackathon 2019")]
body: This was inspired by #1963 , but slightly different. AFAIK, the "Thanks" mechanism already exists in Commons. Is there an API that we can use to allow users to send Thanks via the app when browsing other people's images, similar to "Nominate for deletion" for our own images? Since the framework already exists in Commons, there should be no need for server-side implementation, thus making this a possible task for stuff like the 2019 hackathon #1962 . :) @nicolas-raoul @VojtechDostal

title: Merge 2.9 release with master
body:
**Description (required)**

Merge `2.9-release` branch to master.

title: Upload failures after v2.8
label: [Label(name="auth"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
It seems that we are still encountering upload failures after 2.8, albeit with much lower frequency. I had them today when testing #1968 (however, I created this issue because I don't think it is relevant to that PR, which doesn't alter the auth flow), and had them once on my real device recently.

Logs below from API 27 Nexus S emulator. Interestingly, after seeing this failure, I checked Achievements to see if I was indeed not logged in. However, Achievements works perfectly fine! So my conclusion is that it is the **edit** tokens that are the issue, not the actual login. @maskaravivek

title: Nearby: confusing message about location permission
body:
**Summary:** 
I use an Android 5.1.1 device. Runtime permissions were introduced only in Android 6. When I use the Nearby feature with Location (not the Location permission for the app, the location (GPS) of the phone) turned off, I get an error stating "GPS is disabled" error which is fine. If I give "Cancel" instead of "Enable GPS", I'm shown a error message stating "Nearby places" can't be displayed without location permission. This seem irrelevant as there's no such things as location permission for the app in my device. It's better to improve the wordings a little in this case.

**Possible solution**
When the user taps on "Cancel" instead of "Enable GPS" for the "Enable GPS" pop-up, showing a full screen error page stating GPS needs to be enabled to use this feature might be helpful. It might also contain a "Refresh" icon or something. Asking to enable GPS permission when the user has denied it doesn't seem to be a nice User experience. If he has did it by mistake the "Refresh" icon should help him.

Just wondering, why don't we also allow users to use Nearby to find places needing pictures by manually specifying a location in Maps? This makes the feature usable even without GPS.

**Steps to reproduce:** 
1. Ensure you're using the app on a device with Android version < 6. Also, ensure GPS is turned off.
2. Open the app
3. Go to Nearby
4. Tap cancel for the "Enable GPS" pop-up

Expected: Either Nearby is usable without enabling GPS (OR) a full-screen error is shown stating requirement of GPS (with Refresh button)
Actual: A weird "Nearby permission" pop-up shows up.

**Device and Android version:** 
Samsung Galaxy J1 Ace, Android 5.1.1 (stock)

**Commons app version:** 
2.8.6

**Screen-shots:** 
Just for reference:
![screenshot_2018-06-21-15-30-03](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12448084/48665432-33edf800-ead4-11e8-92c3-eaab97eca76a.png)
![screenshot_2018-06-21-15-30-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12448084/48665435-3c463300-ead4-11e8-9928-032a925880b2.png)


**Would you like to work on the issue?**
No.

title: New main UI - progress bar in Nearby card view sometimes runs forever.
body:
**Summary:** 

Main UI - If we are unable to access the list of Nearby places for whatever reason, the progress bar in the Nearby card view on the main screen keeps going and going. This actually happens fairly frequently for me.

I think there are a few components of this issue:
1. Loading of the nearest place should not carry on indefinitely. If location is unavailable for whatever reason (or, to make it simpler, after a set period of time perhaps), it should say "Unable to load nearest place that needs pictures", with the subtext underneath: "Tap to retry, or swipe to dismiss".
2. It still puzzles me why Nearby is sometimes unable to get a location - when I try using a different map app after Nearby fails, it tracks my location just fine. I don't think this is a recent problem - it has happened before, it is just more obvious when it is on the main screen. We may need to revisit the way we handle locations in the future.

IMO we should at least handle Component 1 before releasing the new main UI. @neslihanturan what do you think?

**Device and Android version:** 

Samsung Galaxy s7 API 26, and also Nexus S emulator API 27
 
**Commons app version:** 

2.9-release branch

**Screen-shots:** 

![screenshot_1542188323](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3611199/48474438-4b17b600-e846-11e8-81aa-9c9ab52a8b38.png)

**Would you like to work on the issue?**

Pref not

title: Allow dynamic loading of contributions, without number limit
body:
There was a request on our mailing list:

> Hello 
> It would be great if we can show images up to 1000 or more. 
> Thank you
> Tris T7
> 

While there are bandwidth and memory concerns with downloading large numbers of images, I personally think if the user decides they want to, we should allow it (however the default should remain the same as currently). Currently the max you can set in Settings is 500. Would this be a good idea?

title: Start Nearby map zoomed in
label: [Label(name="nearby")]
body:
I had a conversation with User:Jim Henderson at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons_talk:Mobile_app#Wish_list , and a concern of his (that I agree with) is that the map frequently auto-zooms out to display an unusable dense cluster of pins, which requires the user to keep zooming back in.

I think that whenever the user starts Nearby, the map should be zoomed in to a reasonable distance (perhaps with the screen width corresponding to 1km)? The reason is that nobody can use the map while it is zoomed out the way it currently is. In order to use it, everyone will have to zoom in - so we should do that work for them.

The Nearby items (pins) however, should be loaded and populate the map to a larger radius (the way it currently works). It is just the initial display to the user that should change.

(Currently we also zoom out whenever the user taps the Nearby list button. That should be fixed too. ;))

This will need to work alongside #591 , but there should hopefully be minimal conflict.

title: Fix for #1942 - App crashing when selecting some specific images
body:
Fixes #1942 - App crashing when selecting some specific images

**Description**
Main reason for the failure is unknown but since stack trace showed the close() call on the null output stream object, null check is required which is recently done via #1918 PR for some other issue but that can be improved upon so that an exception during close of input stream stream should not stop the close of output stream so having a separate try catch block for each.

Also I suspect the main reason why output stream was null and exception could not come in the stack trace was because catch block is handling just the checked exceptions. So I believe expanding it to handle all Exceptions will help us tackle such issues in future.

**Tests performed**

Tested the upload of the image to rule out any regression.

**Screenshots showing what changed**

No UI changes

title: Underscore in author name fix.
body:
Fix for issue with underscore being inserted into username.

Fixes #{#1901} {Issue with underscore being inserted into username}

What changes did you make and why?
After login store string with username without replacing spaces with underscore and passing this string to CurrentAccount as Bundle() in 3rd parameter userdata.

So it can be used when we need authors name afterwards.

title: Show more/less in notification row annoyances
label: [Label(name="assigned")]
body:
**Summary** 

All the times it's turned up for me it's not been helpful - with the 'show more' taking up more space than if it wasn't there. Maybe need to be less aggressive with it? [item_notification.xml](https://github.com/domdomegg/apps-android-commons/blob/2884bd934ab7320ba0918fda937a6a817191e618/app/src/main/res/layout/item_notification.xml#L49)

As the target is small and the middle text link surrounds it, it's annoying to accidentally open the browser.

**Screen-shots** 

Example where it's not that useful

|  Hidden | Shown   |
|---|---|
|  ![screenshot_20181104-143014](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4953590/47965377-6876a400-e03e-11e8-9cb1-1a35fac9f986.png) |  ![screenshot_20181104-143018](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4953590/47965378-69a7d100-e03e-11e8-81fb-59b21b6a19b0.png) |


**Possible solution**

A solution that might solve all of this issue and #1980 is doing away with the "show more", and having the entire notification row be a link. Having a longer trimLength (I'm thinking like 280 chars) with an ellipsis if it's somehow over that should be okay. The user can view the commons website for the entire notification text if it's really long, if they're clicking through to the website anyways.

title: Clicking middle text of a notification row has an inconsistent darkening animation to icon and date
body:
**Summary** 

Clicking on the middle text of a notification row doesn't change the background of that row. However, the icon and the date do. We should show the animation for consistency (also pressing and holding should make row darker shade like others)

**Screen-shot** 

This is the animation I'm talking about:
![screenshot_20181104-142630](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4953590/47965338-b5a64600-e03d-11e8-89f0-b0c4507c3b56.png)

**Possible solution**

A solution that might solve all of this issue and #1981 is doing away with the "show more", and having the entire notification row be a link. Having a longer trimLength (I'm thinking like 280 chars) with an ellipsis if it's somehow over that should be okay. The user can view the commons website for the entire notification text if it's really long, if they're clicking through to the website anyways.

---

Also see #1955, [#1862](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/issues/1862#issuecomment-417689699)

title: When uploading several files at once the date is missing #1854
body:
## When uploading several files at once the date is missing

Fixes #1854 {When uploading several files at once the date is missing}

## Description (required)
While uploading images, current date was being passed as date created instead of the actual date created
Fixes #1854 {When uploading several files at once the date is missing}
Instead of copying the image in a temp file, the app would now use the absolute path of the image to upload images. Also, save the actual date created in ContributionsDao in Column "timestamp" which is currently saving uploaded date [resulting in wrong date being show in web ui]
## Tests performed (required)

Tested on {29l & Google Pixel}, with {build variant, ProdDebug}.

title: General code improvements (refactoring and code style)
body:
**Description**

Improved code quality by:
- Adding 15 more tests
- Move classes into more sensible folders
- Improved readability and performance of some methods
- Added comments and Javadocs where relevant
- Solve FIXMEs in Media.java
- Improve code style

It's probably easiest to review by going through commits separately, due to the move commits. Having tried going through myself to check, I found split view more useful than unified.

**Tests performed**

All automated tests pass

Tested home, nearby (not on API level 15), explore, bookmarks, notifications, settings, about, tutorial, login, achievements, uploading media (from real device only), viewing media (inc. "View in browser" and clicking on license button)

title: Move marketing stuff to a different repository
label: [Label(name="publicity")]
body:
**Summary:** 

Currently the `/design` folder is 136MB, and because git naturally stores file histories it's contributing to the repository being quite a big download. Maybe we could move all of that to a different repo, perhaps `commons-app/design`?

Also if we do this, we might consider removing them with BFG - although caution needs to be taken as some people might be unhappy about changing the git history. At least stopping it early should mean it's not as bad in the future :)

title: Fix for #1959 - Crash on notification and fails on image upload
body:
## Fix for #1959 

Fixes #1959 -  Crash on notification and fails on image upload 

## Description

Error while uploading images is already fixed and is yet to be available on F-droid as discussed in the comments.

Crash after clicking 'Notification' in Android 5.0 happened because of this exception:

java.util.regex.PatternSyntaxException: Unrecognized backslash escape sequence in pattern near index 4:
(^\h*)|(\h*$)
(Full stack trace is in the defect's comments)

Apparently '\s' is the suggested character sequence for white space. '\h' is not getting recognized by Pattern class of Android 5 and 6

## Tests performed

Tested on the following: 

1. API 22 - Android 5.1 - Custom emulator - 1 GB RAM
2. API 23 - Android 6.0 -  Custom emulator - 1 GB RAM
3. API 25 - Android 7.1.1 -  Nexus 5X

## Screenshots showing what changed

No UI changes

title: Idea on "explore"
label: [Label(name="browsing"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="gamification")]
body:
Hello, I have an idea to propose on the explore section in the application.
AFAIK, Random images comes up when the explore is accessed and there is a search function on the page to search "media and categories". Which images related to the search comes up. 
My idea is the implementation of a " favorite " function that will allow users to favorite images. All favorite images will be on a page and the original owner of the image we get a notification every time his/her images get favorite.

One of the benefit is that it will improve quality of images and user that shows quality in their photography work will know there work are indeed valued. 
I can add a pictorial illustrations of my suggestion if needed. ;))

title: Our team at Wikimedia Hackathon 2019
label: [Label(name="2019 plans")]
body:
The [Wikimedia Hackathon 2019](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikimedia_Hackathon_2019) will take place in Prague in May 2019 and I'd like many of you to attend. After all, haven't we had fun at the 2017 prehackathon event in Prague? :-) 

I'd like to include our app as one of the "focus areas" - making it more visible among participants and possibly finding new volunteers for the app development or for its promotion. 

Let's discuss possible things to do during the event. Some of you have good experience with past Wikimedia hackathons - unlike me - and I hope you'll be able to comment on what's doable and what's beyond the scope of a typical hackathon :-)

title: Add template in body of email for Send Log File
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
The newly-revamped Send Log File setting now allows users to send their logs to us, but the email body is very generic. Unless the user takes the initiative to write details, we're not sure what the user is trying to tell us.

A template for the email body would be good. Perhaps something like:

> What problems are you experiencing?
>
> What Android version are you using?
>

body:
## Title (Nearby places icons localization bug fix)

Fixes #{Icons in Nearby list showing up when phone is set to English but not when set to Czech #1852 } 

## Description (required)

Fixes #{Icons in Nearby list showing up when phone is set to English but not when set to Czech #1852}

Place.java: Enum Label was changed from using English word identifiers to QID identifiers. These are obtained from link sent within the query in NearbyPlaces.java. title: Feature #1756 : Bookmark System
body:
## Bookmark System

Fixes #1756   

Creation of a new section Bookmarks in the navigation drawer, divided in 2 tabs.
Those tabs list the user's bookmarked media and places using the previsouly used display.
When clicking a media or a location you can access its details. From the details screen you can now save the picture or place, or unsave it if it is already bookmarked.

Creation of a new package : **bookmarks** including both subpackages **locations** and **pictures**
The subpackages have their own DAO, ContentProvider, Controller and Fragment.
Creation of corresponding tests.

## Tests performed (required)

title: Top crashes in v2.8.4 fix issue #3
body:
## getQuantityString throws Resource.NotFoundException

Fixes #1917 
Title Top crashes in v2.8.4

in `ContributionsActivity.java:306`:

method `displayUploadCount`:

```
getSupportActionBar().setSubtitle(getResources()
            .getQuantityString(R.plurals.contributions_subtitle,
                    uploadCount, uploadCount));

```
`getQuantityString` throws `Resource.NotFoundException`. 

I think there are two possible issues:

1) I went through some strings.xml files in values-{LANGUAGE} folders and noticed that there are languages that have mandatory plurals that need to be defined up for contributions_subtitle(and other plurals as well). The highlight reads, for Arabic for instance:
For example, in ar:

```
<plurals name="contributions_subtitle">
  <item quantity="zero">\@string/contributions_subtitle_zero</item>
  <item quantity="one">%1$d رفع</item>
  <item quantity="other">%1$d مرفوعات</item>
  <!—- need to define additional quantities here (i.e.  “few”, “two”) —->
</plurals>
<plurals name="starting_multiple_uploads">
  <item quantity="one">جارٍ بدء %1$d رفع</item>
  <item quantity="other">جارٍ بدء %1$d مرفوعات</item>
</plurals>

```
`For locale "ar" (Arabic) the following quantities should also be defined: few, many, two`

In [Android documentation](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/string-resource#Plurals):

> Don't be misled either by the fact that, say, two sounds like it could only apply to the quantity 2: a language may require that 2, 12, 102 (and so on) are all treated like one another but differently to other quantities. Rely on your translator to know what distinctions their language actually insists upon.

The missing translations are also seen in the Translations Editor (they are marked in red - hovering over them indicates which literal items are missing).

Some languages don't have a `strings.xml` file, therefore the resource can't be found and the exception is thrown.
I set a default value for contributions_subtitle as 'None' and committed.
## Tests performed (required)

Tested on {API 23, Samsung Note 4 N910H with ProdDebug.

title: Bugfix(#1921)
body:
Title: Fixes #1921: When no internet, nearby stays grey, no spinner nor error 

Description: Fixes #1921: When no internet, nearby stays grey, no spinner nor error 

Area of change: 
NotificationActivity.java ... changed a toast message into a snackbar message which will remain on screen.

Details: 
The reported issue is that in the Nearby activity, the app does not communicate that there is no internet connection.
On investigation, it appears that a toast message does briefly display "No internet connection".
It looks like other activities have implemented this same message within the snackbar instead.
In order to have a consistent style of communication to the user, I removed the toast message and replace it with the snackbar message, as implemented in NotificationActivity.java.

Tests performed:

Tested on API 28 with Samsung Galaxy s8+ via USB Debugging.

1) Log into application		->	You are taken to the "My Recent Uploads" Activity.
2) Turn on airplane mode	->	Your device loses its internet connection.
3) Tap on "Nearby" 			->	The nearby activity will load  the "No Internet Connection" snackbar at the bottom.
								The snackbar message will remain on the screen.
4) Turn off airplane mode	->	Your device regains its internet connection. 
								The Nearby activity will automatically load its contents when the connection is re-established.

title: Versioning and changelog for v2.8.5
Main screen ui changes, fixes #725  Main screen UI overhaul
body:
## Title (required)
Fixes #725 Main screen UI overhaul
## Description (required)

Fixes #725 Main screen UI overhaul. PR is not merge ready yet, but since it is huge, I need some test helps from you to make it merge ready.

- Contributions and nearby are accessible from same fragment now.
- There are two tabs, one holds contributions, the other holds nearby.
- I draw a fragment parenthood tableau for you, because I love you team. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3127881/46733323-a29b9280-cc98-11e8-848a-626d573a0322.png)

- Nearby operations start after selecting nearby tab. They don't directly start on activity create
- Retained fragments are used
- Some leaks occured, since ViewPager is something leak likely, I will be work on it.
- User is able to see if a new notification came after they check notifications activity. 
    - <s> Unread notification icon is a vector drawn by me, but unfortunately it is a incompatible vector type with lover API levels. So please make sure you test this PR on >=M devices. For below, I will be working on this known bug. </s> **Done**
- Nearby notification card view (the thing displays nearest location ) uses its own location manager instance while nearby fragment uses another instance. This seemed to me like the only choice to prevent conflicts (since our location manager is designed to be called from one point, and uses some global state variables)
- If you reject location permission asked from nearby fragment, you will send back to contrib fragment.
- If you swipe and remove nearby notification card view, you need to enable it again from setting page. However, there is a known bug here and HELP WANTED: just swipe right and remove card view, go to settings, re-enable it. Then you will see an empty notification. I have no idea why, and worked enough to understand. A fresh eye would be great. 
- I disabled manually swipe and change page option of view pager. Because it was so hard to use map when this option enabled. Accidental page changes were very frequent.

## Tests performed (required)

Tested on >=M , there is a known bug for below versions. 

## Screenshots showing what changed (optional)
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3127881/46736163-ff02b000-cca0-11e8-956f-d96dbbcf4a71.png)

title: Bugfix/upload via share
body:
## Sometimes uploads fails or queued, then don't upload. #1878
Fixes #1878 Sometimes uploads fails or queued, then don't upload.

## Description (required)
As the app was unable to validate the MIME type of the image shared via intent or from any source, the api to upload image used to fail because the backend was smart enough to validate the same
Fixes #{GitHub issue number and title}

{Describe the changes made and why they were made.}
Added a java library to validate the image MIME type and accordingly append the image extension.

**Summary:** 

Some fields are missing on activity_login.xml landscape and lanscape large versions. They are only added to portrait mode xml file. Thus, it gives NPE when you try to run app on landscape mode.

**Steps to reproduce:** 

Run the app on landscape mode. Ie, "skipLogin" field is missing. I think there may be some other missing fields too, needs to be checked.

title: Fix log reporting for release builds
body:
## Title (required)

Fixes #1489 

## Description (required)

Fixes #1489
- so that the logcat includes logs only from the Commons app. 
- also the amount of logs that is not sent is around 1.5 MB instead of last 100-150 lines
- have removed sensitive logs (needs a comprehensive test to ensure nothing sensitive is still being logged)

I made an effort to fix ACRA error reporting but it still doesn't work for me. I suspect proguard settings might be the issue. 

## Tests performed (required)

Sent logs using send log option. Got logs as expected.

title: Fixes #1914 The info dialog for image description opens only on touch of info icon.
body:
## Title (required)

Fixes #1914 Description info dialog opens when tapped on the EditText in the blank space between hint and info icon.

## Description (required)

Fixes #1914 

The motionEvent.getRawX() used inside the onTouch callback won't work properly if the EditText's parent is not aligned with the left of the screen. Using motionEvent.getX() instead will give the correct value. This will allow the icon to be considered only where it is seen and the dialog is opened on tapping the 'i' icon.
## Tests performed (required)

Tested on Moto G4 Plus (Android 7.0 API 24), with 2.8.3-debug-master build.

_Note: Please ensure that you have read CONTRIBUTING.md if this is your first pull request._

title: Description info dialog opens when tapped on the EditText in the blank space between hint and info icon.
body:
**Summary:** 

While uploading a single image/contribution, the user needs to input the Title and Description. The first description item in the list has the info icon to the right-end and it shows a dialog with the info on touch of the icon. But, it is showing the dialog on touches outside the icon too. 

**Steps to reproduce:** 

- Add a new contribution by selecting Take Photo/From Gallery actionbar-items
- In the next screen, you need to add title and details. 
- Tap on the portion outside the hint "Description" in the EditText. 

 
What did you expect the app to do, and what did you see instead?

**Device and Android version:** 

Moto G4 Plus, Android 7.0, Stock ROM.
 
 **Commons app version:** 

2.8.3- debug master. 

**Screen-shots:** 

![screenshot_20181004-202946](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7912239/46484146-caad7080-c816-11e8-9cef-b1d2ab58bed4.png)
![screenshot_20181004-203001](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7912239/46484149-cb460700-c816-11e8-8079-afc7da3a31d4.png)


**Would you like to work on the issue?**

I'm taking up this issue to solve it.

title: Wikidata items whose picture can not be uploaded to Commons anyway, due to copyright
label: [Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="upstream")]
body:
I arrive to a Nearby place, take a picture, and... realize I can not upload it to Commons due to copyright problems. For instance https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%BC%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA_%D0%9C%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BC%D1%83_(%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BA)

This problem could be avoided if the item was somehow marked as "_No need to go there because pictures of that item can not be uploaded to Commons anyway_". The app could filter out such items, thus allowing people like me to go to more useful places.

First step is to find what exists for this on Wikidata, or propose the idea if nothing exists yet.
https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Project_chat#Photographing_trip:_Mark_items_that_can_not_be_uploaded_to_Commons_anyway?

title: Merge fixes from v2.8.1 to v2.8.3 into master
Versioning and changelog for v2.8.4
Revert to using target SDK hotfix for 2.8.4
body:
Sorry, I've been having issues getting the ideal fix for #1877 to work in 2.8-release, and have been very strapped for time this week. 😞 In the meantime we have been getting a high number of crashes and low ratings due to that.

Faced with the prospect of either having users crash consistently over the next 3 days (long weekend here) or otherwise derailing my RL commitments to spend more time working on the problem, I decided that the lesser evil would be to just change the target sdk for the hotfix so that users can stop crashing immediately. 

The proper fix by Dmitry will remain in master where it already works, and will be released in 2.9 with the target sdk re-incremented. So from a user point of view the fix wil be continuous, the target sdk will not affect them.

I'm not a fan either of the hackish nature of the fix, but it seems like the best way to tie all the moving parts together. I really did not want users to have to crash for 3 more days or however long it took me to figure it out.

Tested all upload flows with this on API 27 emulator.

title: [WIP] Fix build errors from cherrypicking Notifications fix
body:
Cherrypicking #1906 onto 2.8-release does not work out of the box - I had to layer the basics of #1835 under it. 

After fixing all the build errors (including the one that was hiding behind javac), this PR still crashes when uploading on prodRelease. Got to take a deeper look and see if there's anything I missed...

title: Fix crash(es) due to uninitialized notification channel.
body:
The notification channel needs to be created for API versions greater than OR EQUAL to 26 (O).  Also, the channel does not need to be reinitialized if it already exists.
This will likely fix #1877

title: Fix crash(es) due to uninitialized notification channel.
body: Fixes #1877

title: Fix crash(es) due to uninitialized notification channel.
body:
The notification channel needs to be created for API versions greater than OR EQUAL to 26 (O).  Also, the channel does not need to be reinitialized if it already exists.
This will likely fix #1877

body:
From a user on our google groups forum on 13 Sep:

> Hi,
> 
> thanks for your great app.
> 
> Since some days, the app doesn't add, the date of the picture into the template. Is this my fault (wrong settings) or is this a problem with the app?
> 
> And the app puts an underscore into my username. Normally it is “Z thomas“. But since two days it is turned into “Z_thomas“

Very strange bug! I don't recall making any changes in 2.8.3 or 2.8.2 that should affect usernames? @maskaravivek @neslihanturan

title: If front-facing camera, warn that selfies are off-topic
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
1. Check whether the picture was taken with the front camera or back camera
2. If front-camera, display a warning: "Most selfies are off-topic on Commons. Please upload only pictures of notable people or other encyclopedic content"

Unfortunately, EXIF does not have a front/rear property, but if we find a database of phone models we can be guessed it from the model and lens resolution as tipped at https://photo.stackexchange.com/questions/79179/rear-or-front-facing-camera-through-exif-data (also asked at https://softwarerecs.stackexchange.com/questions/52141/library-to-determine-whether-a-smartphone-picture-was-taken-with-front-or-rear-c)

(Inspired from a part of #74 but _might_ be a bit easier to implement)

title: App no longer uses JSoup and Rssparser
body: Editing the readme file to update the libraries used.

title: Update the wiki to show the issues faced during the setup in Android Studio
body:
We should update the wiki 'Develop-with-Android-Studio-or-IntelliJ' to show the issues newcomers face during the setup and how to fix them.  It will save a lot of time that goes in finding the fix by the first-timers if that issue is already witnessed by someone else.

I have attached the 'Develop-with-Android-Studio-or-IntelliJ.md' file in a zip which lists the issues I faced along with their fixes.

[Develop-with-Android-Studio-or-IntelliJ.zip](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/files/2369460/Develop-with-Android-Studio-or-IntelliJ.zip)

title: Fix incorrect Fresco initialization.
body: Fresco only needs to be initialized once, in the Application class. Initializing it again can lead to undefined behavior, including crashes.

title: Fix possible crash(es) due to misplaced vector drawables.
body: Vector drawables do *not* belong in dpi-specific subfolders. They should always be placed in the general "res/drawable" folder. This can actually cause crashes on certain devices.

title: Applying to Google Code-In 2018
label: [Label(name="code-in")]
body:
As applications for [Google Code-In](https://codein.withgoogle.com) are now open, do you think our project would benefit from being a part of this? GCI is a competition that encourages high school kids to contribute to open source software. They do this by completing small tasks determined by us. A task is a small project that is expected to take between 3-5 hours of work to complete and can be about Code, Documentation/Training, Outreach/Research, Quality Assurance(Testing), Design. We would have to create hundreds of tasks for students to work on during the contest period and would be responsible for assigning mentors to help students with questions and to review students’ work on the tasks.

Do you think this would be worth it, or would the hurdle of creating and evaluating tasks be too great for the free high school student labor to be worth it. Personally, this could come in handy for having our app tested more(We could maybe assign tasks such as "Find a bug in the browse feature and create a proper issue") and for creating some rough drafts of the outreach and design stuff outlined in #1889. Of course, how useful these would be is somewhat questionable. I would love to create the tasks etc. but I can't really help with anything as I will be too busy with schoolwork this year.

title: Replace "wikicode" with "wikitext"
body: The usual term in English is "wikitext" and not "wikicode".

title: Write article about our app for Wikimedia blog
label: [Label(name="publicity")]
body: At the end of every grant, I typically write an article for the Wikimedia blog to publicize our new features. :) It will soon be time to write another one. Of course I would need to get Ed Erhart's permission first, but usually they are quite accommodating.

title: Update Play Store screenshots
label: [Label(name="publicity")]
body: We should update the Play Store screenshots soon, as they are very outdated. :) I think only Nicolas or myself can do this. I'll try to sort it out after 2.8.3 is stable.

title: First draft of Project Grant proposal (2019 plans)
label: [Label(name="2019 plans")]
body:
I've finally completed the first draft of the proposal for our Project Grant application! 🙂 If approved, we will start March 2019. Of course, I will need to flesh the proposal out some more before submitting it on-wiki, but I wanted to get everyone's thoughts before I proceed further. Ideally we could come to a consensus on which tasks we want to include in the proposal in 2 wks' time, so that I can start writing the on-wiki proposal then (would like to get it up by the end of Oct to get community feedback, and I will be travelling for 1.5 wks in Oct, so need to plan ahead a bit 🙂). 

This project plan is based on **person-week estimates for 3 part-time developers** with feature loads (the 4th developer will be focusing primarily on bugs/crashes). The initial plan was to apply for a project lasting 9 months (the maximum length that a PG can involve is 12 months AFAIK). However, the number of estimated person-weeks below exceeds that significantly, and in fact is approximately equal to 12 months for 3 devs! So I guess we also have to decide whether we want to keep everything here and extend our plan to 12 months (if all of the grantees are OK with that), or whether we should remove some of the things and scale it down to 9 months. Also, if we want to add something new, we probably have to remove something else.

Feedback from anyone greatly appreciated! @neslihanturan @maskaravivek @ashishkumar468 @nicolas-raoul @VojtechDostal @whym @tobias47n9e @dbrant 

## Proposal draft

We want to focus on our strengths as a mobile app - (1) seamlessly guiding the user to upload photos for locations that need them via an interactive and fun process, and (2) a convenient and stable upload tool especially for people living in the global south, where Commons pictures are often lacking, and mobile phone usage and ownership greatly exceeds PC usage.

There are a few barriers that stand in the way of achieving this:
- The Nearby feature needs to be made more user-friendly and convenient to use, and we need to complete the final link in the chain of collecting pictures for Wikipedia articles that lack them.
- User acquisition in the global south is not as high as it could be due to the fact that our app does not work well with limited connectivity, as well as lack of outreach.
- A large portion of our uploading code is based on sparsely-documented legacy code from the very first incarnation of the app 5 years ago (a long time in the Android development world), leading to unpredictable behavior and bugs sometimes, as well as an outdated upload UI.

This grant aims to address these barriers.

### Targeted acquisition of photos for places that need them:

- **Add filters to Nearby to allow users to filter for certain items.** E.g. Nearby items that have Wikipedia articles, or types of items (instanceOf). Users have different preferences for photo trips, and may want to avoid (or specifically look for) historic buildings, parks, streets, etc. #1450 (8 wks)

- **Allow users to bookmark Nearby items** that they plan to submit pictures for, and to view all their bookmarked items  #1499 (8 wks)

- **After uploading a photo via Nearby, if Wikipedia article exists for it and that article has no relevant images, allow user to add their recently-uploaded picture to the relevant Wikipedia article** (or have a to-do list like Nicolas suggests). We would prompt the user to copy the image code (with filename and caption already prefilled), with brief instructions about where to put it, then load the relevant article via the Wikipedia app or Wikipedia mobile website. (Note: if we go with the app, we should probably talk to the Wikipedia team about this first to ensure that they are OK with it) #872 (8 wks)

- **Fill P2096 (media legend) of P18 image using metadata typed by user.** Insert image descriptions (or title? or both?) into Wikidata as qualifiers. This is quite often done using property P2096. Infoboxes could then read this description when transcluding images from Wikidata. #1831 (5 wks)

- **When user uploads a picture with geotag, check for Nearby items around that location**, and if we find any nearby, ask user "Is this a picture of XYZ?" If they say yes, edit p18 property of that item. #259 (6 wks)

- **Track number of p18 edits** made by user and include them in Achievements screen (5 wks)

Total: 40 wks

### Increase diversity of Commons contributors:

#### Geographical diversity:
- **Limited connection mode** - pause uploads until WiFi detected, don't show pictures (contributions/browse), and use Nearby list instead of map. If possible, also implement ability to pause uploads when a connection drops halfway through the upload, save the chunks already sent, and then continue from there later. #746 (12 wks)

This will be useful to everyone, but especially for people in rural areas and/or the Global South where public wifi is rare and mobile data is limited and/or expensive. The aim is to allow these users to still use features like Nearby list (which uses little bandwidth) to take pictures on the go, but to hold off on high bandwidth operations until they are in a location with wifi.

#### Gender diversity: 

Based on findings by WMDE in their "Charting Diversity" report (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Charting_Diversity.pdf), key action points for improving diversity include (1) image and communication campaigns, and (2) informational/educational films. Quote: "It would also be important to focus on presenting images of female and male editors as well as editors with other gender identities (such as LGBTTI). This would generate more robust role model functions for other potential authors and focus on previously underrepresented groups."

- We will create a **video demonstrating a diverse range of participants talking about our app and using the app to document the world around them**, especially the Nearby feature. Our grantees include 2 women and a range of nationalities, so we will start with that, and we will ask for volunteers in our GitHub community or on Wikimedia mailing lists to participate as well. The video will be basic as none of us are professional videographers (unless we manage to find a volunteer professional video editor), but it should be sufficient for its purpose. We will then put the video up on our Play Store page, website, and blog. #1473 (8 wks)


Total: 20 wks

### Further reduce deletion rate & increase usability of images uploaded

- **Detect selfies** (or more specifically, detect faces that constitute more than a certain % of the image) in uploads, and warn user that only pictures of notable people are allowed in Commons, if a face is detected. There are a few existing Android libraries for face detection, which we can attempt to reuse for our purpose with some modifications. After this prototype is completed, in the future we can consider increasing the strictness (e.g. only allowing uploads of faces by users with a reasonably low revert rate) depending on how reliable the library turns out to be. #74 (8 wks)

- Polish feature that allows users to help **patrol images uploaded via the app** - the prototype was completed during Wikimedia Hackathon 2018, but some additions/changes are needed before we can release it to users. #1559 (8 wks)

- **Unlock features based on number of uploads and revert %** #1869 (10 wks)

- Allow users to **modify or add categories/descriptions afterwards** #161 (6 wks)

- A **to-do list** for the user that contains: (1) images that they uploaded with no categories/descriptions (2) images that can be added to associated Wikipedia articles that have no pictures. The user should be able to filter their contributions list by 'action required' to show only these images. Even if the user doesn't filter, there should be an indicator (perhaps an icon on the bottom right of an image) for actions required. Maybe the 'W' icon for those that need to be added to Wikipedia articles, and a '!' icon for images with no categories/description #1870 (10 wks)

Total: 42 wks

### Increase app stability, code quality and ease of uploading

- **Overhaul legacy upload code and UI.** Our legacy upload backend and UI is still based on its original incarnation from 5 years ago - our volunteers @psh and @ilgazer have kindly paved the way with a few PRs to begin an overhaul. We will pick up wherever they leave off when the grant begins, and ensure that the entire upload process is completely modernized while maintaining feature parity with our current upload process (e.g. implementing zoom, tooltips, the various file checks, all our existing types of category search, etc), and finalize this overhaul.  #1128 (20 wks) (Optional thought: If user has revert rate >50%, we could have a red text warning underneath the declaration and make them tick it manually every time?)

- **Reduce complexity.** As mentioned by @dbrant, we have a high number of third-party components and libraries that are used in our app, thus increasing complexity and the potential for difficult-to-solve bugs and crashes down the road. He has kindly submitted PRs to remove some of the redundant dependencies, but we still have a ways to go. Having implemented a stricter process for including new libraries in our app, we will now go through all our existing dependencies to see if we should keep or remove them, and refactor the code accordingly. #1863 (10 wks)

- **Take a deeper look at our authentication system**, which has been the culprit of several failed upload issues. Notably, 2FA logins still need ongoing checks for the OTP (@maskaravivek could you elaborate on this please?) (5 wks)

- **Further reduce bugs and crashes.** With the new 4th member of our team focusing on bugs and crashes, we intend to reduce the number of open bug issues on our GitHub repo by at least 50%.

- **Write Javadocs for all classes in the "upload" package**. Our eventual aim is to have full Javadocs for every class, but every little bit still makes it easier for new code contributors to get on board. (5 wks)

- Test-driven development, test sheets, and automated testing?

Total: 40 wks (bugs/crashes not included as they will be assigned to 4th member of team)


### New main screen UI

It seems a little bit premature to plan a newer UI when our new UI is still in development, but bear in mind that this "newer UI" will only be implemented at the end of the grant, which will be end of 2019 at the earliest. With the new features that we are planning (and some of the recent features that we already have, e.g. Achievements and Browse), it makes sense IMO to move away from My Contributions being the focal point of the main screen. 

My (very preliminary) thoughts on a potential new main screen UI:

Bottom nav bar: Home, Nearby, Browse, My contributions.

Home (which will be the main activity) could contain:

- "Welcome back, username!" with level badge, stats and achievements displayed
- Unread notifications as bell icon 
- Limited connection mode slider -> more info about this feature above
- News about ongoing campaigns -> this feature to be implemented soon in WMCZ project
- Nearest place that needs pictures 
- Picture being uploaded currently (with option to pause/resume), or if none, the most recent picture uploaded -> more info about this feature above
- Uploaded pictures with action needed  - images without category/desc, or that can be added to Wikipedia articles without pictures -> more info about this feature above
- Upload button (we could probably keep this as a FAB) 

Total: 15 wks

### Finally:

Culminate in v3.0 at the end of the grant period.

### Socialize project

After v3.0 is released:

- **Hold workshops to teach people how to use the app to contribute to Commons**, with focus on either Global South locations, or female contributors. All travel will be local only and it is expected that people will bring their own Android mobile phones (which the majority of people in developing nations use), so costs will be kept low. Perhaps Vivek and Ashish can run one in India (if they agree), and perhaps I (Josephine) or Neslihan might run one for women. Or we will see if any volunteers are interested in running them. We anticipate the total cost for 2 workshops to not exceed USD 500. If this idea is successful, we will iterate on it in the future. #1871

- Put up video showing a few people using Nearby to document the world around them as per "increasing diversity" section

 - **Prepare a list of "things people need to know**" about using the app to upload to Commons (and perhaps instructions on how to do a videocast), then spread the word to other Wikimedia chapters. This will assist other chapters to set up workshops in their own countries if they are inclined to do so.

- Blog posts, mailing list posts, FB/Twitter posts, etc.

Total: 10 wks

Total number of person-wks for all the above: 168 wks

## Metrics of success:
- All tasks completed
- Number and/or percentage of uploads used in Wikimedia articles
- Number of active installs from global south countries (in last 30 days or last 1 yr)
- Number of p18 edits - 1000?
- Deletion rate of <10% while growing active installs to 5000. Many of the new app users could be new Commons contributors, so maintaining the deletion rate with a larger userbase would be a priority
- Open bug issues on GitHub reduced by 50% from the start of the grant
- Number of Wikipedia articles without pictures that had a picture added via our app (Not sure if possible? We have no way of tagging this since the Wikipedia edit won't actually be made from our app)
- Code coverage (for unit tests)?
- 20 new contributors who have never contributed to Wikimedia projects before, from the workshops organized

title: ACRA crash reports do not work again in 2.8.2
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="bug")]
body:
**Summary:** 

When the app crashes, there should be an option to "send feedback" so that users can send their stack trace to us along with comments about what they were doing at the time of the crash.

We already have ACRA for this purpose which used to work, but stopped working again at some point.

If anyone takes this up, please ensure that the logs are sent to the PRIVATE google group, not the public one, due to privacy concerns.

**Steps to reproduce:** 

Trigger a crash on 2.8.2. Not sure how far back this problem goes.

**Add System logs:**



**Device and Android version:** 

8.0 Samsung Galaxy s7
 
 **Commons app version:** 

2.8.2 Play Store version 

**Would you like to work on the issue?**

Pref not

title: [WIP] Refactor feedback and quiz to reduce possibility of NPE
body:
## Title (required)

Fixes #1876

## Description (required)

Fixes #1876

Have refactored some pieces of feedback and quiz to reduce NPE scenario. Have marked the PR as WIP as I have tested it just once and will go through these two modules once again to further handle crash prone cases. 

## Tests performed (required)

Tested both the achievements and quiz module on Redmi 5.

title: Codacy or Travis check for lint warnings in PRs?
label: [Label(name="code-quality"), Label(name="discussion")]
body:
We often realize belatedly that merged PRs contain lint warnings re: potential exceptions, increasing the risk for crashes in production versions after the PRs are merged in. It would be too big a burden to ask our reviewers to manually check the code they are merging for any lint warnings.

Anyone know if we can integrate this check into our Travis or Codacy CIs?

title: Temporary solution for SocketTimeoutException
body:
This is a temporary fix for #1876 as a stopgap measure for the high crash rates experienced by users. It removes the sole entry point for QuizChecker, which calls getRevertRespObjectSingle() upon loading ContributionsActivity.

Ideally we should find a proper fix for that issue so we can reinstate the quiz.

Tested on API 24 Nexus S emulator. Set a breakpoint on `setRevertCount();` in QuizChecker, which is not called when logging in and out or accessing ContributionsActivity otherwise.

(Sorry for the messy commit history, I forgot to rebase instead of merge. :/ However the files changed looks correct.)

I logged in to Misaochan, went to Nearby, and the app crashed for me while I was searching for an image to upload to Nearby. Stack trace seems to point to getRevertRespObjectSingle() in ApacheHttpClientMediaWikiApi

**Steps to reproduce:** 

Unsure of how to reproduce, it is not consistent. However, we should handle this exception more gracefully. I think catching it and outputting an error message is sufficient since that method is not essential (it's just used to get user revert rate). [Edit: After looking into it further, this is NOT true - this function is called whenever the user loads ContributionsActivity, and it is nonNull.]

title: Clear auth cookie while logging out
body:
## Title (required)

Fixes issue where the uploads were attributed to a different account on logging out

## Description (required)

As mentioned in #1866 on logging out, the next upload was being attributed to a different account. I investigated and found out that the `authCookie` wasn't getting cleared on logging out. This PR handles the log out more gracefully. 

## Tests performed (required)

I didn't upload pictures from both the accounts but have verified that the `authCookie` is up to date when a fresh login occurs. I switched between `Testmaskara` and `Maskaravivek` in the same session and found that the cookies were set correctly. 

@misaochan With this fix can you also try making a wiki data edit with a 2FA enabled account. I am hoping that the failures would be less frequent(There's one scenario that I mentioned in #1874 that is still not handled).

title: Add logs in wiki data edit and session refresh flow
body:
## Title (required)

To help investigate #1866

## Description (required)

Have added logs for error scenarios to identify why the wiki data edits fail.

title: Categories with pipe suffix
body:
## Categories with pipe suffix

Fixes {GitHub issue number #1826 and title Categories with pipe suffix} 

## Description (required)
Certain Categories in MediaDetailsFragment used to show up suffixed with pipe. Because of which , when such categories were clicked, the associated images did not show up, because server could not find any images associated because of the pipe suffix. 
Fixes {GitHub issue number #1826 and title Categories with pipe suffix}

Changes made :
-Certain category names used to show suffixed with strings prefixed with pipe '|'. Removed everything after the pipe. As per the discussion on the thread, its safe to remove everything after the pipe, including the pipe

{Describe the changes made and why they were made.}
As a fix, I have looped the category names list and and for each category name if it contains a pipe '|'. It removes everything from the string proceeding the pipe including the pipe. As a result of which, the categories would be shown without the pipe and the clicks on them would show appropriate images.
## Tests performed (required)

Tested on {27 & name of Pixel 2}, with {build variant, ProdDebug}.

## Screenshots showing what changed (optional)
![screenshot_1535870610](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17375274/44952965-a5d97c80-aea9-11e8-9165-5c08e6219777.png)

body:
## Enhancement issue #1862 
Used a SpannableString to setup a ClickableSpan in the middle text of a Notification item so it works the same as when you click at the date in the right side or in the icon at the left.

title: Hold workshops to teach people how to use our app to contribute to Commons
label: [Label(name="discussion"), Label(name="publicity"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
This was inspired by [Shyamal's report](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Grants:TPS/Shyamal/Himalayan_workshop/Report) in 2016 where he used our app to hold a Commons workshop in the Himalayas, citing:

> A discovery was that people of the region are happy to use WhatsApp and Instagram to upload images but seemed to be a bit hesitant about using a browser and were quite happy to see the Upload to Commons app. It seems that there would be great value to localizing this as well as creating some kind of multi-share app that would save people the need to upload a single image to multiple sites and incur additional mobile internet cost.

I was thinking that at the end of 2019, after we have completed most of the improvements that are planned for our PG (trying to be optimistic here! :)), it might be a good idea to run a couple of workshops to teach people how to use the app to contribute to Commons, with focus on either Global South locations, or female contributors. 

If we have volunteers to run them, I can include this in our PG proposal with a request for cost reimbursement. All travel should be local only (or at least low-cost ground transport) and it is expected that people will bring their own Android mobile phones, so costs should be kept low, preferably less than USD 200 per workshop. 

Perhaps those in India (@maskaravivek , @ashishkumar468  , @tanvidadu , @ujjwalagrawal17 ?) could hold a local workshop there, and perhaps I or another woman (@neslihanturan , @tanvidadu ?)  might run one for women. Or any other volunteers?

title: "To-do list" for users
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="categorization"), Label(name="discussion"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
As suggested by @nicolas-raoul , it might be a good idea to display a to-do list for the user that contains:
 - images that they uploaded with no categories/descriptions, so that they can add them (after #161 is implemented)
- images that can be added to associated Wikipedia articles that have no pictures (for #872 )

Perhaps the user could filter their contributions list by 'action required' to show only these images. Even if the user doesn't filter, there should be an indicator (perhaps an icon on the bottom right of an image) for actions required. Maybe the 'W' icon for those that need to be added to Wikipedia articles, and a '!' icon for images with no categories/description?

title: Unlock features based on level (or revert %)?
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="discussion"), Label(name="prevent-vandalism")]
body:
Now that we are able to fetch a user's revert % (and users have levels in Achievements), I wonder if it would be useful to restrict certain privileges based on this? 

Reasons:

- Some features are inherently more vulnerable to vandalism
- To encourage users to level up to unlock more features (similar to Stack Overflow I guess)

Possible features for level-gating:

- Multiple uploads
- Uploading photos that contain faces (risk of selfies)
- Wikidata edits with photos that have no geotags (risk of having 2 projects vandalized instead of just 1)

Thoughts?

title: Reduce complexity - refactor existing code to use unified APIs
label: [Label(name="2019 plans"), Label(name="discussion")]
body:
As posted by @dbrant at #1489 :

> I generally like to encourage a greater emphasis on QA, continual dogfooding, and reducing complexity (i.e. refactoring existing code to use unified APIs), rather than adding further complexity just for the purpose of capturing more detailed logs in the field. Based on a quick glance at the current state of the Commons app, it looks like there's a rather high amount of complexity and dependencies (to the point of requiring multidex? 😮)
> 
> For example, for the purpose of displaying images, you seem to be using Fresco and Glide and Picasso in different places, literally all three major competing image libraries for Android. This introduces a huge amount of bloat, as well as a threefold increase in the surface area for bugs to occur. Not to derail this particular thread, but my earnest recommendation would be to take a step back, establish some best practices for the architecture of the product, and work towards refactoring all of the code to adhere to each of these best practices, one at a time.
> 
> For instance:
> 
> Decide on a single image library (e.g. Fresco) and use it throughout the app.
> Decide whether to use RxAndroid or plain AsyncTasks, and use them consistently (preferably RxAndroid), but don't use both.
> Stop using the long-deprecated org.mediawiki:api library, and use Retrofit (with RxAndroid) for your network calls.
> Evaluate whether you really need all the third-party components and libraries that you're depending on. They are all potential sources of bugs. (For example fr.avianey.com.viewpagerindicator or in.yuvi:http.fluent, both of which have been abandoned for six years)
> Try not to use third-party libraries that promise to "simplify" things, like a library that "simplifies" populating a RecyclerView, or a library that "simplifies" asking for runtime permissions. They are all sources of bugs, which are out of your control.
> Explain these best practices to newcomer volunteers, and reject pull requests that increase complexity unnecessarily.
> Once you do this, the bugs that seem puzzling today will become more and more obvious, or will simply disappear automatically. Sorry for the long-windedness (and apologies if I'm overstepping), and let me know if I can help in any way.

This makes a lot of sense, thanks! I agree that we really do need to sit down and have a discussion about pruning our dependencies. We tend to allow volunteers to add libraries as long as it doesn't introduce any bugs at the time of testing or increase the APK size too much, but indeed we should probably tighten up on that if we want to have a more polished app, due to the increased maintenance required and the increased potential for bugs down the road. An overhaul of the legacy code is also certainly needed.

I would like to introduce this refactoring into our plans for 2019. :) However, we still need to talk about what exactly we want to prune, why we are pruning it, and how to go about it. So, I would invite everyone to chime in with their thoughts on:

1. Which libraries do you think we can remove? In cases of redundancy, which library would you recommend we use over the others and why?
2. What sort of guidelines should we use to determine whether a new library should be added or not, in the future?
3. What other refactoring do you think we urgently need to do?

Once we arrive at a consensus, I can draft this into our 2019 plans.

@maskaravivek @neslihanturan @nicolas-raoul @whym @psh

title: Allow coarser location to be used for Nearby feature
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
**Summary:** 
Sometimes an exact GPS location is not needed and a coarser location is good enough.
If turning on GPS was made to be optional,the app would be useful in such cases (possibly warning of reduced precision).

The main annoyance now is having to turn on GPS, and having to turn it off again afterwards to avoid battery drain. Too much juggling back and forth settings screens for me.
Often, coarse location can be more than enough. For instance, in WiFi crowded areas in cities, where WiFi-assisted location gives 10m accuracy.

**Steps to reproduce:** 
When network (no GPS) location is on, CU keeps asking for enabling GPS (sometimes crashing when canceling). Location permissions have been granted, though. 

**Device and Android version:** 
Moto G5s. Android 7, stock ROM.
 
 **Commons app version:** 
2.8.2

**Would you like to work on the issue?**
I'd like to, but no Android dev knowledge :(

title: Remove dependency on Glide, Picasso, SVG, and multidex.
body:
This removes the dependency on Glide, as well as the SVG rendering library, whose only purpose was to display a single SVG image in the Notification activity. Unfortunately Android doesn't support SVG natively,
but Echo notifications have icons that are SVG formatted. Rather than import a bunch of heavy libraries to support this single case of SVG rendering, we can simply create a few local drawables that correspond to the different types of notifications, and use them instead.

This also removes the (single) use of the Picasso library, and replaces it with correct usage of Fresco.

And because so much bloat has been removed, we can also now remove multidex, since the method count is now well under 65k, and is back in the real world.

title: Sweeping update of gradle and dependency versions.
body: This updates all of the dependencies of the project to their latest versions. Everyone should please upgrade to the latest version of Android Studio, update your build tools, and keep your version of Gradle and the Kotlin plugin up to date.

body:
This gets rid of the single use of the Picasso library (which was causing
the whole library to be imported and shipped) and replaces it with Glide.

or vice versa.

title: Feature/permissions library
body:
## Handle external storage permission in MultipleShareActivity #1697

Fixes {App doesnot ask for permission when multiple pics are shared ISSUE #1697 } 

## The app required external storage permissions which share multiple images from gallery which was not handled properly

Fixes #{GitHub issue number and title}

{Describe the changes made and why they were made.}

Added a library Dexter to handle runtime permissions more efficiently (Note by @misaochan: This has been discussed and approved at #1773 ). Also, in MultipleShareActivity, the following changes were made
Behaviour changes : 
When user tries to share(upload) images to commons via MultipleShareActivity, following decision tree is followed
            a. If the app has permission for external storage, normal upload operation is followed
            b. If the app does not has the permission for external storage, dexter is used to ask for the same
            c. If the user gives us the required permission, normal upload flow is proceeded
            d. If the doesnot gives us the required permission a rationale dialog is shown with the appropriate message to let him know why we need the permission
            e. If he presses okay, steps a-c are followed and if he presses cancel, we close the app.
            f. If while asking for permission, the user chooses never ask again, then next time he tries to upload an image via MSA, the rational dialog follows the app setting screen where he could manually give us the required permission and the onActivityResult of same is handled


## Tests performed (required)

Tested on {27 & name of samsung s7 }, with {build variant, 
 ProdDebug}.

## Screenshots showing what changed (optional)
![device-2018-08-24-235444](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17375274/44601493-48cf2e00-a7fa-11e8-916a-360028cc2466.png)

title: [Peer review] Send message to uploader
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
[Optional enhancement for peer review]

I have found that talking to the uploader is a great way to get them to add details or to determine whether the media is worthy or not.

Examples of how it helped just today:
- I was close to deleting this selfie, but the uploader actually explained how the person is notable (to some extent): https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File_talk:Zhu_(Julian_Zhu).jpg The uploader proceeded to adding description/category.
- A JPG of a diagram, uploaded from mobile, is definitely suspicious. But the uploader actually confirmed they drew the diagram 10 years ago: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File_talk:Concept_usages_technologie_identit%C3%A9_adapt%C3%A9_de_l%27%C3%A9cole_de_design_de_Nantes.jpg

Please note the `{Ping|XYZ}` syntax.

We could even have canned messages, and they could even be localized to the uploader's locale (posted in both the reviewer's language and the uploader's language, and maybe English).

title: Show media talk page
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Each media on Commons has a talk page.

While not as active as on Wikipedia or Wikivoyage, they can still be useful.

We could include the media's talk page discussion (if any) at the bottom of the media details.

Not sure what is the bast way to include:
- Take the wikicode and show it as is?
- Take the wikicode and attempt to make it human-friendly?
- Take the HTML of the page and display the whole thing (that would probably include too much cruft, though)
- Find a Mediawiki API that gives us the rendered conversation part (best)
