title: Completely overhaul app backend (legacy code)
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body:
Talked to @maskaravivek and @neslihanturan about this today. It feels like a lot of time is wasted trying to understand the legacy code in our app and getting new modifications to work well with it. Much of the time is spent patching up something that no one in our team is really familiar with and that was written more than 4 years ago (a long time in Android development). When I talked to the original developer, he said that he created the app when he was relatively new to Android development as well, so he didn't have an answer for some questions on why things are done the way they are. :)

This will be a very long haul task (and will probably not happen anytime soon), but we are considering allocating a few months in the future (possibly for the next grant) for completely overhauling the app backend. The intention is for it to all be modernized and coherent rather than playing patchwork with legacy code.

If we do this, we should make sure to include Javadocs for each class we create so that future developers don't encounter the same problem. 

Thoughts/suggestions? What model/architecture should we adopt if we do this?

title: Decouple upload logic from fragments/activities, unify upload entry points

We would like to get the direct Nearby uploads out first so that users can use the feature, but after that is done we should buckle down and get this sorted.

Scope of this task:
- Remove upload logic from the various entry points and have it all in one reusable module

title: User page edition
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
One user recently expressed deep frustration that they are not able to edit their user page.

Indeed, this is not possible within the app, and not even within the Commons mobile website (screenshot below).

How about adding a simple textbox that allows users to write a simple self-introduction?
It could even be suggested if their user page is currently empty.

A self-introduction is important because it helps reviewers guess whether an image is a copyright infringement or not.
For instance, if my user page says "I am a movie director in Hong Kong", then there are less chances that a reviewer will delete my super-quality picture of Jacky Chan (reviewers are so used to newbies uploading random pics of celebrities that by default they tend to delete if the user has no user page and no contributions)

User with an existing user page would be allowed to edit that page as wikicode. Users who have already set up a complex user page with the desktop website will probably not need this tool.

![unnamed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/35021033-3fe2202a-fb72-11e7-8f18-39e81c4eb725.png)

title: Travis-CI: remove stacktrace from gradle output
body:
I have noticed that '--stacktrace' option creates clutters that are often useless, which in part may be responsible for making people to ignore Travis errors.

It will show us stacktraces for gradle code (such as build.gradle) - since we rarely change gradle code, methods lists like the one below are typically meaningless:

```
org.gradle.api.ProjectConfigurationException: A problem occurred configuring project ':app'.
	at org.gradle.configuration.project.LifecycleProjectEvaluator.addConfigurationFailure(LifecycleProjectEvaluator.java:87)
	at org.gradle.configuration.project.LifecycleProjectEvaluator.notifyAfterEvaluate(LifecycleProjectEvaluator.java:82)
	at org.gradle.configuration.project.LifecycleProjectEvaluator.doConfigure(LifecycleProjectEvaluator.java:69)
	at org.gradle.configuration.project.LifecycleProjectEvaluator.access$100(LifecycleProjectEvaluator.java:33)
	at org.gradle.configuration.project.LifecycleProjectEvaluator$ConfigureProject.run(LifecycleProjectEvaluator.java:103)
...
```

I guess this is an option best to be used locally only when needed.

(I think this will cause an error affected by #1068.)

title: TestCommonsApplication's compilation errors
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="continuous integration")]
body:
It looks like since #1062 TestCommonsApplication has been broken. For example, it tries to override injector() which was removed by the patch.

To quote some of the errors:

```
/home/travis/build/commons-app/apps-android-commons/app/src/test/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/TestCommonsApplication.java:66: error: method does not override or implement a method from a supertype
    @Override
    ^

title: Nearby doesn't recognize when location changed with Fake GPS
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
As mentioned #1065 by @nicolas-raoul : 

> Not sure if related, but recently I had the following problem:
> 1. I was using Nearby with my real location, with items showing normally
> 2. I launched Fake GPS and set my location to somewhere else
> 3. I opened Nearby again
> 4. Got the toast "Location has not changed"
> Even though it is obvious that my location had actually changed.

I also recognized this issue rarely, however, I suspect it is related with a latency of FakeGPG app. Does anyone else experience this isssue on real location changes too?

title: Showing "Location has not changed" toast in Nearby screen when nearby items haven't loaded isn't useful
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
I was on a *wavering network* recently and this lead to sluggish loading of items in Nearby. As I was a little impatient I tapped on the 'Refresh' icon to see if that helps in some ways. Instead of the nearby items I expected, what I got was the "Location has not changed." toast. I don't think showing that toast when there's no items in the Nearby list is the most informative thing we could show to a user. There's something better,
 1. Showing nothing (OR)
 2. Something really informative in that context (no items loaded yet)

So, we have to handle this scenario correctly.

![screenshot_2018-01-14-19-00-48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12448084/34918377-cf734f9a-f977-11e7-9e41-4c6485ff3180.png)

title: Implement direct uploads for Nearby Map
body:
I decided to submit this PR after getting the Nearby Map direct uploads for #252 sorted, and will work on the Nearby List direct uploads in a separate PR. This is aimed at allowing @neslihanturan to start work on updating the user's real-time position in the Nearby Map once this PR has been merged, while minimizing conflicts. I have tested this on an emulator running API 25.

What this PR does:
- Hooks up the camera and gallery buttons in Nearby Map to their respective uploads
- Checks and prompts for permissions as needed
- Saves the title and desc of the Nearby item selected, and autofills the title and desc text fields in ShareActivity respectively
- Applies the #1034 fixes to this branch (as the Nearby code has changed drastically in this branch)

What this PR does NOT cover (and will thus need to be handled in our future PRs):
- Hooking up camera/gallery buttons in Nearby List
- Category suggestions based on Nearby item categories
- Editing Wikidata P18 property
- Fixing memory leaks

title: Add explicit mention of beta server to login screen of beta product flavour
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
We could make it more explicit in the login screen of the beta product flavour that the user is logging in to the beta servers (and that they will need a beta account). 

Rationale: to prevent issues like #1052 (we have had several questions about this), and I sometimes forget myself.

title: Release test flavour to Google Play
label: [Label(name="tests")]
body:
Most people who want to use the test flavour lack the technical skills to compile the APK.
For instance, most of the Google Code-in high school students (who are currently taking screenshots of the app) would not have enough time to compile an APK.

So, it could be a good idea to release to Google Play the flavour that uploads to beta commons.
We would probably need to remove the WMF's names and logo, though, I am not sure whether flavours can do this.

title: At each commit to master, automatically build an APK and send it to Google Play beta
label: [Label(name="continuous integration"), Label(name="tests")]
body:
Since we are using branches, the master branch should always work. In other words, if a bug appears in the master branch then we want to know it immediately.

We have a good number of beta testers (Commons users with no development skills), but betas are rather rare because building and uploading them wastes a lot of the maintainer's time.

Solution:
Whenever something is committed to master:
- Increase the beta minor version number
- Build the APK
- Sign it with the real keys
- Upload it to Google Play's beta

It might sound a bit challenging, but I believe all of the pieces to set this up exist:
- Use Travis to build and save an APK: https://gist.github.com/domenic/ec8b0fc8ab45f39403dd
- Use Google's API to upload the APK: https://developers.google.com/android-publisher/#publishing

title: Recruit volunteers to help with testing
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="tests")]
body:
I was talking to @neslihanturan and @maskaravivek today and the topic of testing came up - our current method is somewhat inefficient because we rely a lot on core developers' time for testing, plus we aren't able to cover a wide range of cases/devices.

It was mentioned that we could perhaps put more effort into designating tasks for people who would like to contribute to our project as testers. I don't think we even need people with QA experience at this stage (though of course if any QAs want to help it would be great!), but if we provide a step-by-step workflow, perhaps novice developers or even non-developers with a bit of technical knowledge could help with that.

Thoughts?

title: Do not show "no description found"
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Even with #1034 fixed there will always be a lot of items with no description.

When no description is found, I think we should just leave the subtitle empty, rather than writing "no description found" to it. I believe "no description found" clutters the screen with a lot of non-information in both map and list modes. The label is always here anyway, so it is not like the item would lose its visual presence.

What do you think?

![screenshot_20180111-115556](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/34806495-aa219246-f6c6-11e7-8d49-15b180989ef0.png)

title: More database related cleanup
body: Moved the construction of Dao classes into Dagger so they can be cleanly injected where needed.  This lead to cleanup of dependencies, and moving some more code into the Dao classes.

title: Avoid crash when service is disconnected
body:
Fixes #1036. 

From the android developer docs it doesn't seem that `onServiceDisconnected` is such an event that the app should be crashed by throwing an exception in this scenario. 

https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/ServiceConnection.html

For now lets avoid the crash by logging the error. As @psh we can move away from dagger injection for this particular service but am not sure if that would eliminate all such crashes.

title: Review how "description" is handled in Nearby
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
As mentioned at #1034 , we currently display Wikidata's "instance of" value of a place in Nearby as its "description" in our app. We also use a compacted form of that value to ascertain what type of place it is and what icon to display for it in the Nearby list

Points of discussion:
- What is the appropriate name for the "instance of" value?
- Should we fetch Wikidata's "description" value as well? If so, do we just display that, or do we concatenate it to "instance of"?

Reposting the last 2 comments on that PR:

whym commented 14 hours ago
> How does 'Classification' sound? 'longDescription' could be simply 'instanceOf' then.
> 
> How do we access Wikidata's true "description"? That may be more suitable for display to users, as a potential enhancement.
> 
> I think it's fairy easy to add a column for it into the query (nearby_query.rq). Not sure how frequently the values are filled given our scope (entities without images) but it wouldn't hurt to add it.


 

nicolas-raoul commented 12 hours ago
> Yes getting the Wikidata description in particular language is easy.
> 
> Most items don't have a description.
> A lot of those who have are like "Church in Paris", which is not much
> better than "church" because our users already know where they are. Some
> description could really provide value though. How about concatenating, or
> using description wgen available?

title: Introduce Room DB abstraction layer to our app
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="question")]
body:
For starters, heres an article explaining room 
https://medium.com/google-developers/7-steps-to-room-27a5fe5f99b2

I recently used Room in one of the projects and found the following advantages. 

- making testing upgrade/functionality of db easier
- cleaner code, removing boilerplate code
- prepare for using livedata/flowables with RxJava
- verifies queries at runtime

It would be great to have thoughts from others. @psh @misaochan

title: Revamp the Settings page
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
- [ ] Categorize the items so that user is able to get what he wants quickly. Possible categories for the currently available content are *Appearance, General, Feedback*
 - [ ] Clarify why disabling "Use Wikidata" would cause huge data consumption. This could be done possibly by using a 'Learn more' link to a page that explains the reason.
 - [ ] The heading 'License' isn't clear enough. 'Default license' would possibly be better
 - [ ] Use [toggle buttons](https://material.io/guidelines/components/buttons.html#buttons-toggle-buttons) instead of [checkboxes](https://material.io/guidelines/components/selection-controls.html#selection-controls-checkbox) as toggle buttons are more suitable for two state settings like "Night mode".

It would be nice if the [material design guidelines for Settings](https://material.io/guidelines/patterns/settings.html) was considered while doing this. I find their suggestion to be one that aims for an intuitive interface.

title: Is it woth showing "Error while caching pictures"?
label: [Label(name="question")]
body: I saw toasts containing the "Error while caching pictures" message several times while I was scrolling through the list of Recent Uploads when the device was offline. That made me wonder why the toast is shown at all. I don't see any *useful information* it is conveying to the end-user except that is distracts him for no reason. What's the rationale behind showing that message? Is it worth showing it?

title: Explicitly show that the license text is a link
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly")]
body:
I saw the [blog post about the recent release](https://cookiesandcodeblog.wordpress.com/2017/12/24/commons-app-update-version-2-6/) and came to know that the licenses were linked. I thought of seeing it in the app and was surprised to see that the text denoting the license was plain. Surprisingly tapping on the text did open the browser make it behave like links while not visually depicting a link. That wasn't something I expected (*[Principle of least surprise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_surprise)*). I might not have even found it was a link if I hadn't read the blog post. I guess it's better to give links their usual distinction (like other links on the same screen).

![screenshot_2018-01-01-20-20-16](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12448084/34469902-23580540-ef4d-11e7-9c48-637a007e30cc.png)

I guess there are two ways to go about it,
1. Really make it a link
2. Give it a link like appearance.

title: Tech-improvement: Better use of dimens.xml for common sizes
body:
This PR addresses the need to have consistent sizing of margins, padding and other layout elements within the app, as requested in issue #886 

For the most part, the app was already fairly consistent just with hard-coded sizes in its layout files directly. A few of the layouts in welcome, login, the drawer and about were adjusted.  In a few cases I left the hard-coded size in the layout file when it was pertinent to that file only.

### Welcome

Font size change for the "heading" and margins/padding changed slightly to standardize.  In a couple of spots there was a layout container or margins that provided no value so was cleaned up.

Showing _before_ on the left and _after_ on the right.
![welcome-01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/407647/34319815-af6767c8-e7b0-11e7-951b-dc421afb192f.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/407647/34319823-d2ac18e6-e7b0-11e7-9bec-a67c1422020b.png)

title: Extracted and tested the database interactions from Contribution.
body:
The goal of this PR is to simplify `Contribution` and get decent tests around its database interactions, particularly the database migrations from version-to-version and construction from a `Cursor`.

To that end

* Database interactions were extracted into a `ContributionDao`
* Tests were added
* Classes that formerly called `save()`, `delete()` on `Contribution` were updated to use a data access object

body:
The goal of this PR is to simplify `Category` and get decent tests around its database interactions, particularly the database migrations from version-to-version.

To that end

* Database interactions were extracted into a `CategoryDao`
* Tests were added

title: Extracted and tested the database interactions from ModifierSequence
body:
The goal of this PR is to simplify `ModifierSequence` and get decent tests around its database interactions.

To that end

* Database interactions were extracted into a `ModifierSequenceDao`
* Tests were added
* Classes that formerly called `save()` and `delete()` on `ModifierSequence` were updated to use a data access object
* Out of date comment in `DBOpenHelper` (reflecting pre-Dagger usage) was updated.

title: Revamp UI of About page and add our FB page link to it
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="publicity")]
body:
Now that we have a somewhat active [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/WikimediaCommonsApp/) , it might be a good idea to add it to the app in a non-intrusive way so that users can follow for updates if they want to (also good for fostering a community around the app). The absolute most non-intrusive way would be to add it to the About activity, though that would be a bit obscure. If we can figure out a nice layout, adding it to the nav drawer instead (via the 'f' icon) could be an idea - though I am always open to opposition. ;)

This could be made a beginner-friendly task once we decide what exactly we want to do.

title: Black background on details and categories screen
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
A student with an Android 4.2.2 Samsung Galaxy GT-S7583T always gets a black background at the details and categories screens:
![](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/master/design/screenshots/Hebrew%20iw-IL/car-description.png?raw=true)
More screenshots with 3 different pictures: https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/tree/master/design/screenshots/Hebrew%20iw-IL
Might be due to relatively low RAM (0.75 GB). Black background is better than crashing, so it is not high-priority. That phone should definitely be able to load the picture though, so we are probably trying to load it in a memory-inefficient way (I assume the same pictures show up fine at the same size in the Android stock gallery). Actually I got this same problem when trying to upload a very heavy picture.

> I left it sitting on the category search for hours once, and the picture never showed up there...

title: Take out legacy event logging from app.
body:
See #995 
These are especially old bits of code, where it seems like WMF folks had set up Eventlogging schemas for some rudimentary analytics of the Commons app. These schemas are no longer queried or monitored, and can be safely removed. When the Commons app has a stronger need for more meaningful analytics, we can revisit reintroducing new and better schemas.

title: Use Wikimedia Maps server instead of Mapbox.
label: [Label(name="high priority")]
body:
See issue #590
This switches to using the Wikimedia tile server for providing map data. It comes with a couple of drawbacks which are currently unavoidable, but such is the way of open-source...
- The WMF map server does not provide vector tiles, or rather it doesn't provide vectors that are compatible with the Mapbox SDK :(
- It provides only one "theme" of tiles, so you will no longer have a dark vs. light theme.

Seems like pushing to production will not be wise with both of the above. Pending these fixes, we will release 2.6.5 which should hopefully FINALLY be sent to production.

title: Salt usernames when logging
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority")]
body: > The app sends data to several eventlogging schemas (owned by WMF) for tracking user behavior in various parts of the app. In these schemas, I noticed that the actual username of the current user is transmitted and stored, unhashed and unsalted.  Ideally the username should be hashed with salt, so that the event logging can be as anonymous as possible.  For comparison, the Wikipedia app generates and stores a random UUID, which it sends in place of the username. This way, we can still track events from the "same" user, but it's completely anonymous.

title: Created a Robolectric unit test replacement for the (failing) NearbyActivity integration test
body:
This PR replaces the almost empty integration test for `NearbyActivity`with a Robolectric based unit test.  This should speed up builds and fix broken tests on *master*.

* Test configuration on the Robolectric tests was made a little more obvious.
* The application method integrating with Dagger was brought into line with the API, facilitating the return of a mock injector in tests.
* Mocks were setup to isolate `NearbyActivity` 
* Fragments in `NearbyActivity` were given tags, to allow for verification.

title: Testing Release build?
label: [Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="question"), Label(name="tests")]
body:
After the current fiasco, I realized that we should probably be testing the Release build (as opposed to just the Debug build) before uploading a new version to the Play Store, lol. The main problem is that testing that build requires the APK to be signed, and the inbuilt "sign APK" UI option in Android Studio just hardcodes the key passwords etc into the gradle file, clearly not an option for an open-source app.

I found several options mentioned at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18328730/how-to-create-a-release-signed-apk-file-using-gradle and am wondering which is the best one to use (since all of them would require some form of gradle file modification). I am leaning towards Gal Bracha's suggestion for ease of use, but I don't see how it allows other people without the key to test the build, as he mentioned.

title: Hopefully fixes crashes on Play Store version
Constant crashes in Release build (current beta in Google Play Store)
label: [Label(name="beta"), Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority")]
body:
When generating a signed APK with the ProdRelease build, I get these errors:

```
C:\Code\GitHub\apps-android-commons\app\build.gradle
Error:Error: commons-logging defines classes that conflict with classes now provided by Android. Solutions include finding newer versions or alternative libraries that don't have the same problem (for example, for httpclient use HttpUrlConnection or okhttp instead), or repackaging the library using something like jarjar. [DuplicatePlatformClasses]
Error:Error: httpclient defines classes that conflict with classes now provided by Android. Solutions include finding newer versions or alternative libraries that don't have the same problem (for example, for httpclient use HttpUrlConnection or okhttp instead), or repackaging the library using something like jarjar. [DuplicatePlatformClasses]
```

I was able to carry on and generate the APK regardless, but we should still probably look into them so that we don't keep getting errors in future versions.

Update: Currently, it seems that in order to release any of the new features post-2.5.0, we will need to:

- [ ] Fix issue with commons-logging and httpclient
- [ ] Fix error with kaptProdReleaseKotlin
- [ ] Re-test ProdRelease build (I am hoping we can find a way for other devs to test release builds as well, see #988

title: Versioning and changelog for v 2.6.0
Refactor login activity to use observables instead of async task
body: Building upon the infra that @psh provided, am replacing the usage of async task for login with RxJava. Doing this refactoring as I wanted to write login UI tests. This PR serves as the base for that.

title: Fix issues around location in nearby activity
body:
- Fixes the issue where nearby list was not loaded in the first attempt. 

How to reproduce?
- Initially phone's GPS is off or the Commons app doesn't have location permissions.
- Either of these things are provided at run time.
- The nearby list just keeps loading. 
- It loads after killing the app. 

The above issue is now fixed. 

- App was continuously listening for location updates and draining a lot of battery

How do you know?
- The location Setting page in the your phone tags Commons app as high battery usage application. 

The above should be hopefully fixed. 
- The app now stops listening for location updates as soon as the nearby list is populated. 
- It again registers the location manager when the refresh button is clicked. 

- App now uses multiple providers to fetch the location. 

Why?

`GPS_PROVIDER` is usually slower. Now the app would be using both `NETWORK_PROVIDER` for coarse location and `GPS_PROVIDER` for finer location. Upon receiving a location update, it will determine if the newer location is better than the last location. If it is, the newer location would be used. 

Also fixes #982.

title: Optional Permissions in Nearby Places activity?
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
On opening `NearbyActivity` when location is disabled, the alert dialog shows the following permission. The text is somehow misleading as its not possible to show nearby places without location permissions in `NearbyActivity`. 

![optional_permissions](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3069373/33229158-3e7158e8-d1ef-11e7-9b12-80ae573ca759.png)

IMO it makes more sense to ask for location permissions, mandatorily in `NearbyActivity`. 
- If the user grants location permissions, load nearby places
- Else finish the activity. 

Comments, @nicolas-raoul @misaochan

title: Remove CSV option for nearby places
body:
Fixes #979. 

Have simply made a PR for the discussion going on in #979. It can be merged if there's no opposition on removing the CSV.

title: Rename? GitHub will help potential first-time contributors discover issues labeled with "help wanted" or "good first issue"
label: [Label(name="debated")]
body:
> Now, GitHub will help potential first-time contributors discover issues labeled with "help wanted" or "good first issue"

Should we rename our existing "beginner friendly" label?

Also, would it make sense to use the "help wanted" label?
I guess all of our non-discussion issues would have it, so I have doubts.

We would have to modify our up-for-grabs.net configuration too.

label: [Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="question")]
body:
The "load from CSV" option is a relic of our initial Nearby prototype before we switched to using Wikidata queries. Personally, I think Wikidata is superior in all aspects and I have never used the CSV option after Wikidata implementation because the CSV takes about 5 minutes to load each time. Nobody that I have talked to currently uses the CSV either.

We were discussing removing the CSV entirely at #291 , and some were supportive of it. Benefits of removing the option in my opinion:
- Simplifies the implementation of further Nearby enhancements (e.g. direct uploads)
- Allows us to close all issues caused by the CSV without wasting developer time solving them
- Prevents potential cases of a user accidentally tapping that option in Settings and then wondering why Nearby takes forever to load for him
- Simplifies testing

What do you guys think? Is there anyone here who would prefer we keep the CSV option?

title: Use modified branch names for APK
body: Using branch name and version name in APK to make testing easier. It will have the following advantages: - Simply looking at the APK name, its version and branch name can be identified. So while working on multiple branches building the APK won't be needed every time. - The About page will show the current version details ie branch name, latest commit ID for debug builds. This will help in easily verifying that we are on the correct build while testing. The release build will keep showing just the version number as it used to be earlier. ![version_name](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3069373/33186263-372c242e-d0ae-11e7-9d43-7031bc438cce.png) @neslihanturan This might make your life easier. :)

title: Call setupPlaceList() onResume in NearbyActivity
body:
In our current master, there is an issue with Nearby Places not loading at all - the progress bar runs forever. After digging around a bit, I figured the reason is that `setupPlaceList(this)` is only being called in refreshView and not when the activity is loaded.

This fixes that problem in my tests, but there is a small issue where the very first time Nearby loads (on a newly started application), it says "No Nearby Places found", probably because the GPS hasn't had time to get a fix yet. The second time onwards, this works fine. 

But would be great if anyone could build on this to fix that, perhaps by delaying the first load until a location is found?

title: Fix: Location update in nearby activity
body: Fixes #973.

title: Send log file to private Google group forum instead
body: As mentioned at #891 , WMF has pretty strict rules about how we maintain user privacy if we are to remain on their Play Store account. When the user taps "send log file" in Settings, they should be sending the file to the private forum (only accessed by devs who have signed the NDA), not the public one.

title: "No nearby places found" in NearbyActivity (pre-release)
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="pre-release")]
body:
While currently testing master, after loading NearbyActivity, I get the "No nearby places found" error. Tapping refresh does not solve the problem.

This happens consistently on my phone (Samsung Galaxy S7 running Android 7.0). I am never able to get the Nearby list/map on my phone in the current master. I have GPS on, which is currently displaying appropriately in other apps (E.g. Google Maps, Zomato, Foodora).

On an emulator (Nexus 7 API 25), Nearby works only after sending the coordinates through, then closing the app manually and re-launching it. Refresh button does not work. Switching activities does not work.

This used to happen occasionally for me on our current Play Store beta version, but the prevalence seems to have increased significantly on our current master. We will probably have to delay our planned release until the issue is solved.

title: Use different package name for debug and release variants
body: Fixes #969. This seems to be happening as the debug and prod versions of the app share the same package name. Ideally they should have separate packages. Different package name would also facilitate testing both versions simultaneously. As seen in the screenshot the package name `fr.free.nrw.commons.debug` package is being displayed for debug build.

title: Localized category search
label: [Label(name="categorization"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="localization"), Label(name="upstream")]
body:
Less than 1 in 4 persons in the world can understand basic English.
Only 36% of the world population use the Latin alphabet.

So, for most people the search bar does not return the right things, for instance typing "España" in our app's category search bar does not make the "Spain" category appear.

This is a core problem of Commons, where categories only have an English name. [Structured Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:Structured_data) (a project spanning from 2017 to 2019) might solve this, though that might require some input and stearing from us.

A workaround for now is to take the appropriate label from the category's Wikidata item, for instance "विकिपीडिया:श्रेणी" from https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q6741108, but it only has labels for very famous things. This workaround does not allow for fuzzy search though. I am not sure whether we should implement the workaround, or just wait for Structured Commons to be deployed, which might happen in a few years, or might never happen since there is some opposition to this big change, as well as serious technical challenges.

_(also posted at Structured Commons' [discussion page](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons_talk:Structured_data#User_story:_Our_app_needs_a_way_to_localize_Commons_categories))_

title: Report that Nearby item is not at specified location
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
Sometimes Nearby makes me go to a place, and I realize that there is nothing, for instance it was supposed to be a museum but it is just fields. This probably happens to any regular Nearby user.

This leads to frustration, and if nothing is done the point stays on the Nearby map, and another person (or forgetful me) might be tricked by it again.
But this could be turned into a very positive experience that benefits Wikidata: Let the user report the point.

Implementation could be a "Report" button that proposes:
- The item is not found around that point
- The point is a bit further
- The item does not exist anymore at that place
Feedback could be appended to a particular Wikidata maintenance article such as https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/User:Syced/Commons_Mobile_App

title: Create screenshots for YOURLANGUAGE
label: [Label(name="code-in")]
body:
_(Only for Google Code-in)_

Requirement: "YOURLANGUAGE" must be a language that you can read and write very well, typically your native language. For instance, if your native language is Telugu and you can write in Telugu, then follow the instructions below and write the pictures names/descriptions in Telugu.

# A. Context
- Commons is a big repository of images that are used in Wikipedia.
- Commons Mobile App is an Android app that allows volunteers to upload pictures taken with their phones.
- Screenshots are one of the main ways for new users to learn what the app is, its goal, and to understand how it works.
- The app's description page currently only has screenshots in English, which is unfortunate for people whose native language is not English.
- So, we want screenshots of the app in many other languages.
- These screenshots will be examples for the users, so they must be of high quality, the instructions below will lead you in this process.

# B. Preparation
1. Get or borrow an Android phone (not a tablet).
2. Set it to portrait mode (not landscape).
3. Install the [latest version of the app](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=fr.free.nrw.commons).
4. Start the app and create an account. Your username will be visible to everyone on the Internet, so choose something not too personal and not offensive, for instance `Pablo8374` is OK.
5. In your phone's camera app, [enable GPS](https://www.phonearena.com/news/How-to-turn-GPS-location-tags-on-and-off-for-your-photos-on-Android_id64932) to store location.
6. The next step will be taking pictures. Please understand these rules for pictures:
- It must be pictures that you have taken. Not pictures taken by other people. Not pictures downloaded from the web. ([more info](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Commons:First_steps/Contributing))
- The pictures must not be too dark, so it is better to take them in a bright place, during the day, outside.
- The pictures must not be blurry. Hold the camera firm when taking each picture.
7. So, take three pictures:
  a. One picture of your school's main building ([example](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CD_Girls_Inter_College.JPG)), please also note the exact name of the school, and the name of the building if it has a name.
  b. One picture of a car ([example](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Audi_80_V1_restylee_2.JPG)), please also note the car's brand and model, and the name of the street or neighborhood. If you are in a place with no cars at all, a picture of another vehicle (such as a truck/tractor/motorbike/bicycle) is acceptable too.
  c. One picture of a restaurant ([example](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:2012_Cairo_7381841634.jpg)), please also note what kind of food the restaurant serves, and the name of the street or neighborhood.
7. [Switch your phone's language](https://www.wikihow.tech/Change-the-Language-in-Android) to YOURLANGUAGE, if not done already. For example, if you want to create screenshots in the Telugu language, then change your phone's language to Telugu.

# C. Take screenshots

## Nearby
1. Start Google Maps or another app that uses the GPS, and make sure the GPS can see where you are. You might need to go to the window to get GPS signal. You must be in a place with an Internet connection, though.
2. Start the Commons Android app.
3. In the side menu, tap "Nearby".
4. Let the page load, it should take less than a minute.
  - If you get a message like "No nearby places found", it most probably means that the app failed to catch a GPS signal in time, so go outside to a place with a good view of the sky, restart your phone so that everything is clean, start Google Maps or another GPS app to make sure you have a GPS signal, then start Commons and try again.
  - If it still does not work, or if you don't have an Internet connection outside, install https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.lexa.fakegps then restart your phone, start Fake GPS, set the location to a city near your place, press the green button, then start Commons and try again. It should work in any case.
5. Zoom a bit so that the blue markers are a bit everywhere.
6. Swipe away all notifications, to make the screenshots cleaner.
7. [Take a screenshot](http://www.makeuseof.com/tag/6-ways-to-take-screenshots-on-android/).
![nearby-map](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32837980-e02be742-ca52-11e7-9fec-bf406a4a49d6.png)
8. Press the "list" icon in the upper right.
9. Swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![nearby-list](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/47553200-64ad9800-d941-11e8-9879-de5b9c663bb0.jpg)

## School
1. Go back to the main screen of the Commons Android app.
2. Tap the "Picture" button, which is the most top-right button (on the right of the "Camera" button).
3. Select the school picture.
4. Enter as a name `Main building of the school ABC in DEF`. Replace `ABC` with the school's exact name and `DEF` with the street or neighborhood name, and translate to YOURLANGUAGE, for instance Telugu.
5. Enter as a description `This school teaches students from level GHI to JKL`. Replace `GHI` and `JKL` with the appropriate levels, and translate to YOURLANGUAGE.
6. Before going to the next step, swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![school-description](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838000-ebef718e-ca52-11e7-8710-b3ab640cf1e8.png)
7. Press the "Send " icon in the upper-right. 
8. You will now have to select the most appropriate categories for the picture. If you took the school picture in Dhaka then the most appropriate category is [Schools in Dhaka](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Schools_in_Dhaka). Categories are all in English. Try to find a category called `Schools in MNO` (replace MNO with your town or state or country name). If you can't find, choose the category `Schools` and the category for your town or state, for instance `Dhaka`. [This page](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Schools_by_country) may help you find the exact name of the best category. Then select the category by tapping the check symbol on the right of the category so that it turns green.
9. With the category name visible in the search bar but the keyboard hidden (you may need to press Back once to hide the keyboard), swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![school-categories](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838014-f7609232-ca52-11e7-9ac5-1f2ea13286b1.png)
10. Press the "Save" icon in the upper-right.
11. The image should have appeared in the app's main activity. Click on it to reveal the details activity.
12. Swipe up a bit to reveal the image's information. Still let a little bit of the image visible at the top so that viewers understand what it is about.
13. Swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![school-details](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838024-ff211460-ca52-11e7-8725-1d0945929a65.png)

## Car
Repeat the same steps (two screenshots) with the following:
- Name: `Car by maker ABC, model DEF`. Replace `ABC` and `DEF` with the car's maker (example: `Toyota`) and model (example: `NS4`), and translate to YOURLANGUAGE, for instance Telugu.
- Description: `Picture shot in GHI`. Replace `GHI` with the street or neighborhood name, and translate to YOURLANGUAGE.
![car-description](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838062-21c1bf92-ca53-11e7-8636-b1c24dd81e76.png)
- Category: Look for a category called `JKL vehicles`. Replace `JKL` with the maker's name, for instance [Toyota vehicles](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Toyota_vehicles). [This page](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Schools_by_country) may help you.
![car-categories](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838079-311ed182-ca53-11e7-972b-623177a03bb1.png)
![car-details](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838083-339ca844-ca53-11e7-935a-4d4a781f310b.png)

## Restaurant
Repeat the same steps (three screenshots: description, categories, details) with the following:
- Name: `Restaurant in ABC`. Replace `ABC` with the street or neighborhood name, and translate to YOURLANGUAGE.
- Description: `This restaurant serves DEF`. Replace `DEF` with the kind of food the restaurant serves, and translate to YOURLANGUAGE.
![restaurant-description](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838166-65bea3d6-ca53-11e7-9e4f-632f35d55f2c.png)
- Category: Look for a category called `Restaurants in GHI`. Replace `GHI` with the town or state's name, for instance [Restaurants in Quito](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Restaurants_in_Quito) [This page](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Restaurants_by_country) may help you.
![restaurant-categories](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838172-6bde9e92-ca53-11e7-9462-ebe0dac33814.png)
![restaurant-details](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838176-6e281fde-ca53-11e7-8019-f84bc9471745.png)

## Gallery
1. Go the app's main activity. It shows all of your uploaded pictures.
2. Swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![gallery](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838188-772e8320-ca53-11e7-9b49-864c7e988881.png)
3. Swipe from the left to make the left panel appear
4. Swipe away all notifications, then take a screenshot.
![menu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32838196-7f548e82-ca53-11e7-9888-7c808838e86b.png)

## Gather the files
1. Put all screenshots into a folder and rename them according to what they are:
  - nearby-map.png
  - nearby-list.png
  - school-description.png
  - school-categories.png
  - school-details.png
  - car-description.png
  - car-categories.png
  - car-details.png
  - restaurant-description.png
  - restaurant-categories.png
  - restaurant-details.png
  - gallery.png
  - drawer.png
2. Check again that you have all 13 files above.
3. If you want, you can add more screenshots of things you found interesting.

# D. Send a pull request
1. Find a desktop computer.
2. Create a [Github](https://github.com) account if you don't have one already.
3. Install [GitHub Desktop](https://desktop.github.com/) (if you are familiar with Git, feel free to use your favorite Git tool instead).
4. [Fork](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/) the [Commons Mobile App's marketing repository](https://github.com/commons-app/marketing).
5. [Clone](https://help.github.com/articles/cloning-a-repository/#cloning-a-repository-to-github-desktop) your forked repository. Be sure to clone YOUR own repository, not ours.
6. Find the folder `marketing` folder on your computer, then inside it `screenshots`.
7. Within the `screenshots` folder, create a new folder with the name of YOURLANGUAGE and its code and your nickname, for instance `Telugu te-IN Pablo8374`.
8. Within that folder that you created, put all of the screenshots.
9. [Select and commit the files](https://help.github.com/desktop/guides/contributing-to-projects/committing-and-reviewing-changes-to-your-project/#2-selecting-changes-to-include-in-a-commit) with the commit message `Added screenshots for YOURLANGUAGE` (replace with your language), then push.
10. Go to https://github.com/commons-app/marketing/pulls and click the button "New pull request", then submit the pull request to us ([tutorial about pull requests](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request-from-a-fork/)).
11. We will review your contribution, merge it into our repository, and award you the task :-)

_If you have trouble with this section, please search on the web for a Git tutorial, and try again. If after really trying hard you still don't manage to get it right, then you can also send us the files in a ZIP by email to nicolas.raoul@gmail.com mentioning the language and why you had problems with Git._

title: Google Code-In: Setup development environment and run tests
label: [Label(name="code-in")]
body:
- [Download Android Studio 3.0](https://developer.android.com/studio/index.html)
- [Install and configure git on your machine](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git)
- Create github account
- [Fork apps-android-commons repository on github](https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/)
- [Clone your fork into your local machine.](https://help.github.com/articles/cloning-a-repository/)
- Import your freshly cloned repository into Android Studio. This might take a while.
- Try to build and run app on your android device / emulator.
- In console run `./gradlew clean check connectedCheck jacocoTestReport --stacktrace
` to execute unit tests.
- Provide results of your tests, and screenshot of running instance. If any of unit tests are failing please document it in this issue.

Feel free to contact us if you have any problems.

title: Convert tests into Kotlin
body:
I suggested writing tests in Kotlin in #747. Andrdoid Studio 3 is out and Kotlin is now supported by default, so I thought we might want to move forward in this area.

I'm not sure implications in relation to other libraries like Rx we are using, though. I'd appreciate reviews especially from that regard.

title: Zooming does not work when pinching with the finger on the same horizontal line (on Nearby map)
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="upstream")]
body:
Zooming/unzooming depends on where your two fingers are placed.

It is a bit difficult to explain, but if you think of an analog clock:
- Fingers at 12 and 6: Zooming works
- Fingers at 3 and 9: Zooming does not work

title: Dependency injection with Dagger
body:
This PR has been waiting in the wings for a while and completes the work for #890, to inject dependencies everywhere in the app using Dagger.  I feel like this story closes #890.

The driving change here is that code should not be reaching back to the main `CommonsApplication` for dependencies - they should all come from Dagger.  Along the way that meant introducing a few classes to clean up operations that the application class was doing that it shouldn't (for instance, session management) and refactoring to allow for *constructor injection* of dependencies for some existing classes that were reaching out to the main application.

title: Fixes NPE in Util function
body: Fixes #211.

title: Take latitude/longitude from picture taken seconds after
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
When I go photohunting and finally reach that historical remain after walking for kilometers, I usually take several pictures with slightly different lighting/angle. I usually take about 5 pictures of the thing, and when I am back home I judge which one is the best.

Problem: The first few pictures usually do not have GPS information. And quite often the first picture is the best. Actually, when uploading from Android I usually have the gallery app showing each picture fullscreen, and I swipe in chronological order, so the one which I upload to Commons is usually the first I took, often without GPS info.

Solution: When the user tries to upload a picture with GPS info, try to find a picture taken within 20 seconds after which has GPS info. Then show a screen showing the two picture and asking "Did you shoot these two pictures at the same place? Do you want to use the latitude/longitude of the picture on the right? And use it. Do not use GPS orientation as orientation can totally change within a second. The worst error would probably be someone taking serial shoots from a running high-speed train, that's why the confirmation step is required.

Technically that could be done by reading the chosen picture's file creation date and folder, then listing the files in that folder by creation date, and reading the EXIF of the ones after until either you find GPS coordinates or the EXIF has more than 10 seconds. A "phase 2" enhancement could be getting the EXIF's GPSDOP parameter (measurement precision) to use the one with the best precision, as GPS sometimes takes a bit of time to get precise.

title: Export location of nearby missing pictures to GPX file
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
The "Nearby missing pictures" map exists, but many people would probably prefer to see the location of their favorite maps app such as OsmAnd/Maps.me/etc.

So, it would be great to have an "Export to GPX" button that asks you for the desired radius, and generates a GPX file containing all of the latitudes/longitudes. KML/KMZ formats could be a nice addition.

The KMZ file for the whole world (generated by my script https://github.com/nicolas-raoul/wikidata-missing-pictures-offline) takes 100MB, so a default radius of 100km sounds reasonable.

Another advantage is that the file can then be used offline, for instance if you only have WiFi at the hotel r in your home country. Being able to select the center would be a nice addition, for instance letting you download all of Cuba's points while preparing your trip at home in Pakistan.

I tag "beginner-friendly" because while it takes some time implementing, I believe there is nothing really difficult technically. The Wikidata query is already present in the code, and GPX format can be copied from the Github project above.

KMZ file seen on Maps.me:
![screenshot_20171113-104437](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/99590/32706337-38ca7296-c860-11e7-8d1a-e4cda8c7e23e.png)

title: Implement upload button to allow the user to select Camera or Gallery
body:
Making a sub task from #252. 
Implement upload button, making sure to check for necessary permissions and to allow the user to select Camera or Gallery. The scope of the task is to to refactor the upload interactions. 

Instead of having two buttons on the `ContributionsActivity` there can be a single upload button and on clicking it, a dialog will open which would look similar to: 

![choose_image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3069373/32692111-469c32f2-c738-11e7-90ab-ed6118b178f2.png)

This refactoring will help in continuing the flow from #922. From the mocks, it looks that we will have a single button for uploading in the `NearbyActivity` and there too the same code can be reusing for choosing and attaching the image. 

Another advantage will be the extensibility it would offer. It will be very easy to add other file types like PDF, audio and video later.

[This query](https://query.wikidata.org/#select%20DISTINCT%20%3Furlatlas%20%3Fitem%20%3FitemLabel%20%3FlieuLabel%20%3Fdateconsult%0Awhere%20%7B%0A%20%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP195%2Fwdt%3AP361%2a%20wd%3AQ3044768.%20%0A%20%3Fitem%20%28wdt%3AP276%7Cwdt%3AP361%29%2F%28wdt%3AP276%2a%7Cwdt%3AP361%2a%29%20wd%3AQ1075988.%0A%20MINUS%7B%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP276%20wd%3AQ1075988.%7D%0A%20MINUS%7B%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP276%20wd%3AQ40091273.%7D%0A%20MINUS%7B%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP276%20wd%3AQ19675.%20%7D%0A%20%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP276%20%3Flieu.%0A%20OPTIONAL%7B%0A%20%3Fitem%20p%3AP276%20%3Fdeclarationloc.%0A%20%3Fdeclarationloc%20prov%3AwasDerivedFrom%20%3Fref.%0A%20%3Fref%20pr%3AP854%20%3FURLref.%0A%20FILTER%20regex%28str%28%3FURLref%29%2C%20%22cartelfr.louvre%22%29%0A%20%3Fref%20pr%3AP813%20%3Fdateconsult%20.%0A%20%7D%0A%20MINUS%7B%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP18%20%3Fimg.%7D%0A%20OPTIONAL%7B%0A%20%3Fitem%20wdt%3AP1212%20%3FIDatlas%20.%0A%20wd%3AP1212%20wdt%3AP1630%20%3Fformatterurl%20.%0A%20BIND%28IRI%28REPLACE%28%3FIDatlas%2C%20%27%5E%28.%2B%29%24%27%2C%20%3Fformatterurl%29%29%20AS%20%3Furlatlas%29%0A%20%7D%0A%20SERVICE%20wikibase%3Alabel%20%7Bbd%3AserviceParam%20wikibase%3Alanguage%20%22fr%22%7D%0A%7DORDER%20BY%20%3FLieuLabel%0A) shows Louvre paintings without a P18 image, with location information.
To my surprise, "location" is extremely specific: It is the room number inside the Louvre.
So while this may be a rare case, including location information might be a good idea. Maybe only if the specified location is fine-grained enough? Not sure how easily this can be decided, though.

title: Check image coordinates for direct Nearby uploads in locations that the user is not currently in
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
After #591 and #252 are both implemented, there is concern that #591 could potentially increase the risk of vandalism via direct uploads, since the user would not need to be in a location (or to even spoof their location) in order to upload a picture for that Nearby item. When P18 edits are implemented, the consequences of this could be even more severe, as the Wikidata items will actually be edited and removed from Nearby.

If we allow direct Nearby uploads for items in locations that the user is not currently in, we should check the geolocation of the image (via EXIF data) and disallow the direct upload if it is not within a close radius of the Wikidata item location. 

Not sure what we should do if the user simply did not enable geotagging on their camera, though...

title: Detecting pictures that are too dark
body:
As discussed in #74, this attempts to detect 2 kinds of unwanted pictures:
1-Images that are too dark
2-Images that are blurry. 

When the app detects an image which it finds to be too dark or blurry it shows a popup with an error message. The popup is basically a warning since the user can choose to ignore it and continue uploading the image. 

As for the image processing part,  detecting images that are too dark works quite flawlessly as per my testing. I have never come across an image that was pointed out as being too dark incorrectly or vice versa. 

On the other hand, while blurry images detection works well enough, the results become less consistent for images taken during the night and/or in poor lighting. It isn't that it fails every time, just that every now and then you will run into an image which looks sharp but was marked as blurry by the app. I have tweaked and played with the configuration quite a lot with the current setup working best for me. However I am not completely convinced. 

That said, having worked on it for quite a while, I felt best to put the code out for others to see. Maybe having some fresh eyes could lead to changes/improvements.   

P.S: I have added the OpenCV library to the repository as part of this pull request. However I found [this](https://github.com/jlhonora/opencv-android-sample/blob/master/.gitignore) gitignore file that suggests excluding the library from the repository. This will need to be discussed. 

Also we will definitely need to add a section in the Wiki about setting up OpenCV.

title: Develop new UI for Nearby item view pane, to include Upload option
label: [Label(name="IEG"), Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
In our implementation of #252 , we need to think about where the "upload image for this item" button will be, and in the process figure out if the existing Nearby item UI needs to be overhauled.

Options:
1. We leave the current UI mostly as it is, but replace one of the two bottom navigation buttons (probably "read article") with "upload image"
2. We design a different viewpane for Nearby items (perhaps taking inspiration from @psh 's suggestions at #873 )
3. We keep the viewpane simple, where the user would just use that as a platform to launch a new fragment with more details and options for that Nearby item

I am personally leaning towards Option 2, but would love to get more input/suggestions.

title: IEG renewal approved - updates and progress (and new assistant project maintainer)
label: [Label(name="IEG")]
body:
Hi all,

Our IEG renewal application has just been [approved](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Grants_talk:Project/Improve_%27Upload_to_Commons%27_Android_App/Renewal#Renewal_approved). :) We (Vivek, Neslihan and myself) plan on starting on 23rd Oct if we receive our agreements by then. 

I will be updating this with a timeline and the measures of success shortly, and we can use this thread to track IEG updates and progress. We will also be tidying up the issues soon, assigning the IEG-related issues to grantees and filling up https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/projects/3

Also, we would like to welcome @neslihanturan as the new assistant project maintainer. :) She will be responsible for testing and merging PRs, organizing issues, supporting volunteers and new contributors, and generally keeping the repo in good shape. 

Many thanks to all the volunteers and contributors who have stayed with us through the past few months! We hope to make lots of progress on the app soon.

title: Login screen improvement
body:
This PR closes issue #899 - the login screen UI improvements.  Based on feedback in the issue, the error message text was modified to more closely follow Material Design guidelines which state

> Error text should reflect your product’s color palette. It’s recommended that 
> you use a contrasting color for error states, such as a warmer hue like red or orange.

While making the changes I also simplified the `styles.xml` (to remove complexity that wasnt being used) and setup the correct colors in `colors.xml` for a nice Material Design color palette.  See issue #899 for screenshots.

~~**Note:** `app/src/main/res/values-hi/strings.xml` was having problems and this commit contains the workaround (adding a `formatted="false"`) which doesnt actually solve the underlying problem but did stop the compile failing.~~ (fixed with changes merged in from master)

title: User reported that their current location is appended to image EXIF data by default
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
I recently received a complaint where a user believed that their current location was appended to the EXIF of their uploaded image without their consent. After doing a bit of digging to refresh my memory, it seems to me that this should not happen. As mentioned at https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/wiki/Category-suggestions-%28readme%29 , the user's current location should only be collected and appended to the uploaded image (and used for category suggestions) if the user explicitly enables the setting for that. That is certainly the case for me when I test it.

Does this happen to anyone else?

title: Travis CI failure related - String resources format
body:
After cloning the repo and attempting to build the app using `./gradlew assembleDebug`, I got this error: 
```
Error:(56) Multiple substitutions specified in non-positional format; did you mean to add the formatted="false" attribute?
Error:(56) Unexpected end tag string
Error:(56) Multiple substitutions specified in non-positional format; did you mean to add the formatted="false" attribute?
Error:(56) Unexpected end tag string
```

A quick google search led me to this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4414389/android-xml-percent-symbol

Escaping the %-symbols with a `%` in https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/master/app/src/main/res/values-hi/strings.xml#L57 seems to silence the issue and the build completes successfully. However, it would be good to have someone more familiar with the project double check whether or not this is an actually an issue and if it is, whether this really solves the problem.

title: Become the replacement for Panoramio
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="publicity")]
body:
Panoramio was a hugely popular app to send pictures of places. The user could choose the license, and many chose an open license.
It [was shut down last year](https://ssl.panoramio.com/maps-faq) after it was acquired by Google in 2007.

When you look for pictures when editing a Wikipedia articles, a large proportion of the images come from Panoramio, so the closure of Panoramio is a big loss for Wikipedia.

We should strive to get former Panoramio users to use Commons rather than Google's replacement (which is not open).

Tasks (feel free to add more):
- Find former Panoramio users (please post below if you are one) and ask them what they miss from Panoramio.
- Get the word out that Commons can be a replacement for Panoramio, highlighting the advantages over other replacements.

title: Actions needed to keep app on WMF Google Play Store account
label: [Label(name="IEG")]
body:
WMF has been talking to me about the actions needed in order to keep our app on their Google Play Store account. The list of actions we have agreed upon is as follows:

- [x] Nicolas, myself, and anyone with access to the crash reports forum will have to sign NDAs. If anyone wishes to relinquish crash report forum access instead of signing the NDA, that's fine too.

- [x] Modify disclaimer for app store listing - I will do this shortly based on Aeryn (WMF lawyer)'s recommendations

- [x] Modify disclaimer for About page in app - we will need to do a release for this to be effective

- [x] Finish drafting new privacy policy - https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/wiki/Privacy-policy (must mention Mapbox). #520 could be useful here.

- [x] Implement OAuth for login #819 - waived

- [x] Release modifications to production, inform WMF that everything on our side is complete

- Security reviews - the WMF Android team will be reviewing our app for security concerns shortly, and will schedule further reviews in the future, but there is nothing we need to do on that point currently.

title: Tech-improvement: Introduce dependency injection using Dagger2
body: Dagger2 is dependency injection library which will help to remove many initializations of some utils/loaders/api workers and etc. For example in current project it will help to initialize SharedPreferences client once for using in many parts of app. _(the runtime for Dagger is tiny, it's mostly compile-time annotation processing)_

title: Tech-improvement: Use Glide for image loading / caching
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body: Use [Glide library](http://bumptech.github.io/glide/) instead of asynctask load of images. Glide already developed for loading images, and its support different paths for imageview (URI, URL, file path at SD card and etc). Simple use, simple result.

title: Tech-improvement: Refactor high-complexity classes
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body: Address the very high cyclomatic complexity we are seeing from Codacy by breaking up Activities & Fragments according to one of the well-respected architectural patterns (MVP / MVVM / etc)

title: Tech-improvement: Use SVG format icons
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body: Move icons to SVG format instead of PNG, which will decrease APK size and improve icon multi-screen support

title: Tech-improvement: Better use of dimens.xml for common sizes
body: Most common sizes must be moved to dimens.xml and separated by screen-sizes folders. Too much values are hardcoded in layouts

title: Tech-improvement:  JSON based Wikimedia API
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body: Move to the [JSON based WIkimedia API](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/API:Data_formats) as XML is officially deprecated by Wikimedia as a format. We already include OkHttp and GSON in the build, so no new libraries would be needed.

title: Tech-improvement: Use 'newInstance' pattern for fragments
label: [Label(name="code-quality")]
body: For fragments, use the [newInstance pattern](http://www.androiddesignpatterns.com/2012/05/using-newinstance-to-instantiate.html) instead of creating new objects directly. Fragment newInstance() pattern prevents memory leaks and makes it obvious what arguments are used by the fragment.

title: Nearby notable things from OpenStreetMap
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
Wikidata only has 2000 embassies, while OpenStreetMap has 8000.
All embassies are notable enough to have their picture in Commons.
OSM has gotten quite good at linking to Wikidata, so an OSM item without a Wikidata link probably is not in Wikidata yet.
So, let's display them in Nearby, as soon as technically possible.
An advantage of OSM is that the items are all current (all buildings still exist in the present day, if you go there you will have something to take a picture of). 
When the user uploads a picture,
1. Create a Wikidata item with the correct type, such as embassy, name/description, image, lat/long from EXIF if available (not from OSM for license reasons)
2. Link to it from the OSM item. This task is probably better left to a bot, and the Commons app would only send data to that bot (in order to avoid authentication issues and to be able to modify the code that talks to OSM without having to force all app users to update).

I believe OSM items with these tags are notable (every instance is worth having its picture in Commons):
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:amenity=embassy
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:diplomatic=consulate
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:diplomatic=embassy
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:amenity=hospital
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:building=hospital
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:man_made=bridge
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:building=bridge
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:place
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:railway=station
- https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:tourism=zoo
- (please add more)

title: After user uploads an image directly from a Nearby item, edit Wikipedia article to include image that was just uploaded
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
As discussed in #252, we might want to allow the user to edit the associated Wikipedia article to add the image, after the user has successfully uploaded a pic for a Wikidata item. This would complete the "chain" of seamless workflow after the other improvements at #252 are completed during the renewal - users can browse the places that need photos, select one and move to the location, directly upload the photo after taking it (with suggested titles and categories based on the Wikidata item), and THEN add it to the Wikipedia article that is associated with that item. 

We could see if the Wikipedia app allows us to do that, or otherwise link to the web view. Otherwise, we could also implement the functionality in our own app if other options don't suit (last resort).

Considerations: 

- We must include a tutorial on how to do so
- We must consider the user's Wikipedia language version as well as how to implement the UI in a clean manner
- We should log (or tag) the edits that are made via our app to ensure that we aren't vandalizing articles.

title: Push / native / system notifications
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
The topic "native Android push notifications" popped up in several issues in the last few days: e.g. #870, #865, #725, #7, #858, #79, #259.

I posted my thoughts in several of them, but as this tends to hijack the actual feature discussion, I wanted to centralize that information in one place:

Native push notifications would certainly be a nice technical feature and could greatly enhance some functionality. But they pose some very serious challanges:

1) Server Side Component
Unfortunately, native notifications require a server side component that a) either polls for new "messages" on Mediawiki or b) is informed about new "messages" by MediaWiki. It also requires a "database" of "push tokens" that are connected to user accounts (unless this can somehow be added to the mediawiki user account) and are used by the serer component to send the notification to the actual device. (It gets more complicated when a user has multiple devices.)

2) Google Play Services
As far as I know the only battery friendly way to support push notifications on Android is using GCM/FCM which is implemented via Google Play Services on the device. From what I read in the past, this might be a problem for the project because of licence / Open Source rules reasons.

Does one of the official Wikipedia apps have push notifications? I would like to look into how they implemented this...

Alternatives to proper push notifications include a) local notifications (where the app or a service trigger a notification to be generated themselves, looks identical to push but happens all on the device) or a b) "pull notification" system which works similar to e.g. the Facebook feed where you have to refresh a list of messages to get new messages (or which gets refreshed automatically when the app is started or running).

title: New message notification by email
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
We would like to make sure the user notice messages they have received. In the Wikimedia Commons community, more often than not, missed talk page messages can cause trouble. (In the worst case, the user can be blocked for "ignoring warnings".)

We can ask the user to enter their email address so that we can let them receive notifications by email. I believe we can use https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/API:Edit_-_Set_user_preferences and https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/API:Options for this.

As a related enhancement, we also could have native notification. (but not strictly necessary if we have email) See also the issue on Echo integration (#7).

I find the new onboarding screens of the wikipedia app to be a good alternative. It's currently only in the [alpha](http://android-builds.wmflabs.org/). I could help with this if it's ok to change it.
