title: IEG renewal: Remaining steps
label: [Label(name="IEG")]
body:
For anyone who is interested in our IEG, I am listing the steps that need to be done before the previous IEG is considered complete, and the steps needed for renewal. At this stage, I think the chances of the grant being renewed will likely depend on endorsements (as well as how the committee judges my proposal). If anyone has any suggestions, feedback, etc, please do let me know.

Remaining steps for wrapping up IEG:

- [x] Solve urgent issues #693 
- [x] Create Youtube video #331 (whoops, almost forgot about this)
- [x] Final publicity step #420 
- [x] Collect measures of success metrics
- [x] Write final report based on those metrics
- [x] Have the IEG committee accept and sign off on the final report

Steps for renewing IEG:

- [x] Talk to Marti from the IEG committee (have not had a response from her)
- [x] Draft renewal proposal (including anyone who is interested in being part of the grant team)
- [x] Submit renewal proposal - https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Grants:Project/Improve_%27Upload_to_Commons%27_Android_App/Renewal
- [x] Community announcements and endorsements
- [x] IEG committee makes decision

title: Fixes #671: Ability to launch welcome activity again
body: Fixes #671

title: IEG renewal proposal
label: [Label(name="IEG")]
body:
After this IEG round is over (basically, just the final publicity step and the final report left), I intend to apply for a renewal. 

**UPDATE: The final draft is available at https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Grants:Project/Improve_%27Upload_to_Commons%27_Android_App/Renewal . I am no longer updating the opening post.**

# Tasks

Please bear in mind that the time estimates below are not just for development, but also for testing, getting user feedback and fixing any issues with implementations 

'Nearby places that need pictures' enhancements: (1.5 mths)
 * When user selects an item on the nearby list or map, there could be an option for them to upload a picture for that item. They can choose camera or gallery to take the picture.  #252 
 * After a picture has been taken or selected, they could be taken to title/desc screen. Title/desc screen could have an option for "use suggested title and description" which would fill in the fields with the title and description of the Wikidata item
 * Category suggestions could be offered based on the categories associated with the Wikidata item (in addition to other category suggestions)
* After a successfully uploaded picture, the app should add the image to the Wikidata item via editing the P18 property (needs to be monitored at the start to make sure we are doing it right)
* [unsure] After a successfully uploaded picture, the user could be asked if they would like to edit the corresponding Wikipedia article (if one exists) - either via the Wikipedia app (if installed) or Web View
 * User could be notified of places near them without photos.  Clicking notification should take them to the item in the nearby list or map #259 
* Show real-time position on Nearby map #686  (after improving how location is updated #674 )
* Tell user what Nearby places actually is and does - either through adding a brief description to the UI or a one - time pop-up

Quality of life improvements: (1 mth)
* Enable 2 factor authentication #328 
* Fix battery drain issue ( #724 )
* Deleted photos should not be shown in contributions list #118 
_* [Not included] Add support for videos? #4 (not sure how much work this would take)_

UI improvements: (1 mth)
* User should be able to select multiple uploads from gallery when initiating the selection from within the app instead of only via "Share"
* Upload and camera buttons should be placed in a more obvious and easy to reach location ( #725 )
* [unsure] Users can view photos that other people have uploaded near them ( #725 )
* Nicer login screen - a few people have said that the current one doesn't look good
* Nicer nav drawer with username and maybe picture of the day displayed

_[Not included] Make app more interactive:_ 
_* [Not included] Badges - I think we want to stay away from pure quantity badges like "200 uploads" so we don't inspire bad uploads. Rather, we could offer badges for quality, like when the user maintains a 90% no deletion rate, or when their pictures are used in articles or selected as picture of the day etc. Also not sure on the feasibility of this as it would require backend storage online #85_
_* [Not included] Add campaign support (not sure if feasible in addition to everything else, might take a lot of work). A "lite" version of this could be just displaying news about ongoing campaigns/competitions #78_ 

Improve user education to improve uploads:deletion ratio:  (1 mths)
https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22user+education%22
* Display account notifications to user  (e.g. picture has been nominated for deletion). #7 

Various important technical stuff: (1.5 mths)
* Allow dummy uploads 
* Implement upload tests #705 
* Fix overwrites #703 #228 
* Improve event logging #734 
* Fix the top 10 crashes (by number of reports) listed in Google Developer console
* Fix memory leaks (esp. in ShareActivity.java)
* Fix "high priority" bugs

# Metrics of success

* All tasks completed
* Number of uploads from our app that are used in wikipedia articles - we could get this from [wmflabs](https://tools.wmflabs.org/glamtools/glamorous.php?doit=1&category=Uploaded+with+Mobile%2FAndroid&use_globalusage=1&projects%5Bwikipedia%5D=1&projects%5Bwikimedia%5D=1&projects%5Bwikisource%5D=1&projects%5Bwikibooks%5D=1&projects%5Bwikiquote%5D=1&projects%5Bwiktionary%5D=1&projects%5Bwikinews%5D=1&projects%5Bwikivoyage%5D=1&projects%5Bwikispecies%5D=1&projects%5Bmediawiki%5D=1&projects%5Bwikidata%5D=1&projects%5Bwikiversity%5D=1)
* 500 (?) P18 edits in Wikidata (see #252 )
* Uploads:deletion ratio
* [Unsure of] Test coverage?

title: Urgent issues that should ideally be fixed before final publicity step
label: [Label(name="IEG"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="publicity")]
body:
As requested by @neslihanturan . :) I get that we can use labels, but the list itself is up for discussion, so instead of discussing it on the individual issues, we can discuss the general plans here.

My intended date to start the final publicity step (PR releases to general media, as I have already written for the Wikimedia blog and approached blogs that have written about us before) is 5 June 2017 or thereabouts. So the list needs to be attainable within a short period of time, no big suggestions please unless you think you may be able to pick the task up yourself. :)

My suggested tasks:

- [x] Make sure that #668 has been fixed in the recent patch
- [x] #650 
- [ ] #674 
- [x] Either revert to targeting API 23 or fix #457  
- [x] #686 (fixed, the further enhancement is not urgent)
- [x] #671 (if possible)

title: Add a marker and circle of accuracy for current location
body:
Currently the user's position is not visible on the map. This
commit adds a marker to the user's position and a circular
polygon which shows the accuracy of the location measurement.

![screenshot from 2017-05-28 17-41-05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6953323/26530137/1421a2e0-43cf-11e7-8654-5c1048b648b0.png)

title: Fixes #654: Upload count
body:
This PR fixed the upload count shown in the header. 

It also introduces some infrastructure for handling concurrency in the app. I will add some documentation on its usage. 

Feel free to go through the PR and see the usage of 
- background thread using `ThreadPoolExecutorService`
- the usage of `ListenableFuture` in the `UploadCountClient`

title: The messages "Commons Article" and "WikiData Article" may need improvement
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="localization")]
body:
The word "article" is appropriate for Wikipedia, but not for Commons and Wikidata.

If "Commons Article" refers to a file description page in Wikimedia Commons, then it should say "Commons file page" or "Commons description page", or "File description page in Commons".

If "WikiData Article" refers to an item page in Wikidata, then it should say "Wikidata item" or "Wikidata item page". (And of course, "Wikidata" is not CamelCase.)

Both messages also need message documentation (qqq). The easiest way to fix this is to edit the qqq pages in translatewiki.net and write the explanations there:

* https://translatewiki.net/w/i.php?title=Wikimedia:Commons-android-strings-nearby_info_menu_commons_article/qqq&action=edit
* https://translatewiki.net/w/i.php?title=Wikimedia:Commons-android-strings-nearby_info_menu_wikidata_article/qqq&action=edit

title: Please explain "Welcome Wikipedia" and "Welcome Copyright" messages
label: [Label(name="localization")]
body:
The messages "Welcome Wikipedia" and "Welcome Copyright" look a bit strange. Why isn't it "Welcome to Wikipedia", for example? And why Wikipedia and not Wikitravel or Wiktionary? And what does "Welcome Copyright mean at all?

The easiest way to fix this is to edit the qqq pages in translatewiki.net and write the explanations there:

* https://translatewiki.net/w/i.php?title=Wikimedia:Commons-android-strings-welcome_image_welcome_wikipedia/qqq&action=edit
* https://translatewiki.net/w/i.php?title=Wikimedia:Commons-android-strings-welcome_image_welcome_copyright/qqq&action=edit

Perhaps the English messages themselves should be changed, but I'm not sure.

Thank you!

title: Please explain the message "Media Image Failed"
label: [Label(name="localization")]
body:
The message "Media Image Failed" is unclear, and it doesn't have message documentation ("qqq"). Where does this message appear? What is a "Media Image" and what can be the reasons for its failure? Etc.

The easiest way to fix it is to edit the qqq page in translatewiki.net and write the explanations there: https://translatewiki.net/w/i.php?title=Wikimedia:Commons-android-strings-mediaimage_failed/qqq&action=edit .

Thank you!

Don't pass/store Activity instance in key places.
body: This chain of commits goes a long way towards fixing/preventing memory leaks. Also, one of the commits fixes a crash in API <21 where loading of vector drawables is not supported.

title: Always remove TextWatchers when finished with them.
body: This can lead to memory leaks.

title: Fix crash when uploading multiple photos.
Fix usage of deprecated function String.fromHtml(String)
body:
String.fromHtml(String) is now deprecated. This patch fixes that by adding a method to Utils that selects the appropriate function based on the user's platform.

Util method lovingly reused from the Android Wikipedia app which is Apache licensed and therefore compatible with this codebase.

https://github.com/wikimedia/apps-android-wikipedia/blob/master/app/src/main/java/org/wikipedia/util/StringUtil.java#L115-L126

title: Simplify if statements in Utils and ExistingFileAsync
body: This patch simplifies a few if statements by replacing them with returns, which helps improve code readability and simplicity.

title: Remove redundant call to String.format() in CategoryModifier
body: This patch removes a call to String.format that can be replaced with a literal string which is much clearer and easier to understand.

title: Remove unused imports
body: This patch removes imports across the codebase that are unused to improve code maintainability and cleanliness.

title: Remove redundant field in SettingsActivity
body: There is a field that is set in SettingsActivity that is never used at all. This patch removes that field to improve performance and code tidiness.

title: Vertically center nearby list loading icon

at the very top of the view.
This commit vertically centers the loading icon.

title: Position is  not updated by nearby
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
It is still possible to get a empty Nearby list with GPS turned on and position available.

Steps to reproduce in emulator:
1) Turn off GPS
2) Go to Nearby list (don't turn on GPS)
3) In NearbyActivity `curLatLong` will be `null`.
4) List is empty
5) Turn on GPS
6) Go to home screen
7) Back to nearby.
8) In NearbyActivity `curLatLong` will still be `null`.
9) Change location using the emulator.
10) This fires in `LocationServiceManager` the `onLocationChanged` method.
11) Next refresh will now again contain items.

Waiting for Android to detect a location change might not be the best way to get the current location.

title: Fix crash of nearby list when the places list is null
body:
Currently the NearbyController crashes when it is called with a
places list that is null. This is caused by the NearbyMapFragment
not handling this state correctly.
This commit adds tests for an empty list and null, which reproduce
the problem. An early return in the NearbyController can make
the tests pass, but might not be the best solution for this issue.

title: Fix the backstack
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience")]
body:
Steps to reproduce

1. Go to the Home
2. Click Home again in navigation drawer
3. Repeat the above step (2) twice
4. Select Nearby in the navigation drawer
5. click the back button
6. It will leads to the Home
7. Click the back button again
8. It reloads home

The problem is it keeps the same page in the backstack more than once if it is accessed more than once in continuous clicks in the navigation drawer.

Linked to #612 .

This PR changes 2 files. Currently to remove all elements from a collection we use `removeAll(c)` but `clear()` is more efficient and saves time.
Changed to `clear()`.

title: If an item that doesn't exist anymore, indicate that
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
This building was destroyed in 2007, as tipped by its Wikidata "end time": https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q11311478

We should hide such items, or maybe at least display "Does not exist anymore" or "Past object" or something similar.

The current Wikidata consensus seems to be that if no ancient picture/painting is available, then a picture of nowadays ruins is OK, but a totally-changed nowadays place picture is not OK:
https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property_talk:P18#Destroyed_building:_Is_a_picture_of_the_current_place_nowadays_OK.3F

In case of an ancient battle, there might be a plaque, but there is another property for plaque image: https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P1801

title: Fix lat-long format and add tests
body:
Currently the lat-long string in the gallery still contains
negative numbers. Also W values do not work correctly.
This commit fixes the calculations and adds tests for the
LatLng class.

title: Image detail view: Back icon opens nav drawer

title: Crash: Fragment State loss exception
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
The app is crashing as we are trying to commit the fragment `onPostExecute` call of an `AsyncTask` but theres a possibility that the `onSaveInstanceState` has already been called for it. Here's a [blog post](http://www.androiddesignpatterns.com/2013/08/fragment-transaction-commit-state-loss.html) explaining why this happens. 

```
FATAL EXCEPTION: main Process: fr.free.nrw.commons, PID: 10644
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Can not perform this action after onSaveInstanceState
 at android.support.v4.app.FragmentManagerImpl.checkStateLoss(FragmentManager.java:1842)
 at android.support.v4.app.FragmentManagerImpl.enqueueAction(FragmentManager.java:1860)
 at android.support.v4.app.BackStackRecord.commitInternal(BackStackRecord.java:649)
 at android.support.v4.app.BackStackRecord.commit(BackStackRecord.java:609)
 at fr.free.nrw.commons.nearby.NearbyActivity.setListFragment(NearbyActivity.java:247)
 at fr.free.nrw.commons.nearby.NearbyActivity$NearbyAsyncTask.onPostExecute(NearbyActivity.java:219)
 at fr.free.nrw.commons.nearby.NearbyActivity$NearbyAsyncTask.onPostExecute(NearbyActivity.java:166)
 at android.os.AsyncTask.finish(AsyncTask.java:651)
 at android.os.AsyncTask.-wrap1(AsyncTask.java)
 at android.os.AsyncTask$InternalHandler.handleMessage(AsyncTask.java:668)
 at android.os.Handler.dispatchMessage(Handler.java:102)
 at android.os.Looper.loop(Looper.java:148)
 at android.app.ActivityThread.main(ActivityThread.java:5417)
 at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method)
 at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit$MethodAndArgsCaller.run(ZygoteInit.java:726)
 at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit.main(ZygoteInit.java:616)
```

The issue is similar to #435 but its because of a different code path. And the fix in this case would be different as described in the blog post.

title: Replace 'removeAll()' with simple 'clear()'
body:
In [Media.java:176](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/8aa14e7bf5f318fc0f0b53a8d7e0290ed5c191bd/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/Media.java#L176), [MediaDetailFragment.java:238](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/8aa14e7bf5f318fc0f0b53a8d7e0290ed5c191bd/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/media/MediaDetailFragment.java#L238) and [MediaDetailFragment.java:283](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/8aa14e7bf5f318fc0f0b53a8d7e0290ed5c191bd/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/media/MediaDetailFragment.java#L283) all uses a form of :
```java
 categories.removeAll(categories);
```
which is less efficient and (potentially) takes longer. Instead, we should use `categories.clear()`. A simple `clear()` is much faster for emptying the ArrayList.

title: Port to desktop computers
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
I move recent pictures from my phone to my computer every week/month because of storage space limitations. Then to upload the interesting pictures to Commons I use [apps like Vicuña](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Mediawiki_upload_tools).

PROBLEM: In some cases the Commons mobile app is more efficient than these desktop apps (ex: guessing category from latitude/longitude, or reusing latitude/longitude from a picture taken just after).

So, it would be great if we could use the app on desktop.

Originally making the APK into a Chrome app sounded like the best thing to do, but Google hsa deprecated such apps. I am not sure what is the best way to port now.

### Original post, out-of-date

I tried generating a Chrome extension from the APK using Twerk, but the resulting extension loads forever, without even making it to the splash screen.
[shashlik](http://www.shashlik.io) gets a bit further but stuck as well:
![Android Commons app on Ubuntu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/99590/26007549/ead3265c-377b-11e7-804d-3c05fff6b3e8.png)

It would be really good if this could be changed to say something like 'Showing 500 of 2540 total uploads' so that you can easily see how many files you have uploaded in total. This is not a feature that is easy to find on Commons itself, so it would be a nice feature which might encourage more people to use the app.

title: Show number of satellites and Circular error probable in Nearby
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
I think it is important to show the user how accurate the current position is while looking at the Nearby view. There are two important measures:

* Number of visible satellites (Stepping away from a wall can sometimes get you way more satellites). So a low number has a lot of meaning for experienced users.
* Circular error probable (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_error_probable). Most hiking GPS give 50% accuracy. I would prefer to give the 95 % accuracy value. This is usually displayed as +- 100m, which means that your true position is within a 100m radius with a probability of 95%

I think ideally the card should have a QR code of a link to the Play Store page, or at least a short link you can type quickly.

In addition to the design, logistics (printing and its cost) would be an issue, though.

title: Allow the user to proceed after being warned by AbuseFilter
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
On the website, once the warning is shown, the user can choose whether to cancel it or ignore the warning upload it. The app currently does not allow the choice, and treats it as a failed upload. We would like to provide an experience similar to the website by showing the warning and asking for confirmation.

For example, Wikimedia Commons currently gives warnings to small JPG files contributed by new users: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:AbuseFilter/156

It doesn't appear that many new users of the app are affected by the particular filter above (maybe because smartphone pictures tend to be large enough), but I think it's good to be ready for it. Abuse filters that affect a wider range of contributions may be added anytime by the Commons sysops, for example to fight against sudden increase of vandalisms.

Note also not all AbuseFilter rules allow this choice. Some rules are designed to immediately reject an upload or edit without asking the user.

For details on how to programmatically interact with the AbuseFilter system, see https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:AbuseFilter#API .

A screenshot with AbuseFilter asking for confirmation:
![failed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10674/25563188/8f5a1cee-2dd1-11e7-9d76-b53d03e8a97e.png)

title: Rename and refactor tests
Logging at hackathon
body:
I have seen the idea of keeping individual, public logs in a beginner-friendly mini hackathon/coding workshop:  https://github.com/oss-gate/workshop/blob/master/tutorial/scenario.md (in Japanese). I haven’t tried it before and I’m not sure if it is the best format for us, but I find it inspiring. The idea is like this (at least this is my understanding):

- Each participant keeps a public log, adding every update they have during the hackathon (tools they have tried, references they have found, other attempts and failures they experienced during the day). It could be a wiki page on MediaWiki.org or a GitHub issue (maybe in a dedicate repository).
- When mentors alternate between different participants and topics (in addition to their own dev tasks) they can refer to the logs to keep themselves updated. In other words, it helps people work asynchronously.
- The log doesn’t have to be a complete write-up. Think something like “Tried to reproduce the XYZ bug. Stuck at a different error: …” or “Checked the official doc. It doesn't explain how to XYZ.”
- Participants should feel free to include basic matters such as trying to setup an environment or thoughts that may or may help others later on (e.g. “This feels kind of similar to the XYZ software I worked on in terms of ….”).
- If someone feels it is an obstruction, they don't have to follow this practice thoroughly. (But still, having a paragraph or two for a day can be recommended.)
- Of course, when appropriate, consider also posting to an existing or new GitHub issue instead of the personal log.

The main benefit is that reading the logs helps mentors to help mentees. The logs also may serve as a starting point towards making the software documentation more complete (this can happen post-hackathon).

title: Move config file of PMD
Tutorial messages use line breaks instead of '\n' after being translated
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="localization")]
body:
Tutorial messages that use `\n` for stylistic purposes actually appear in https://translatewiki.net as if having actual line breaks. Here's an example original message:
```
  <string name="tutorial_2_subtext">- Natural objects (flowers, animals, mountains)\n- Useful objects (bicycles, train stations)\n- Famous people (your mayor, Olympic athletes you met)</string>
```
Shows as https://i.imgur.com/PYVYX4A.png

And naturally gets translated into:
```
  <string name="tutorial_2_subtext">- Objets naturels (fleurs, animaux, montagnes) 
- Objets utiles (bicyclettes, gares ferroviaires) 
- Personnes célèbres (votre maire, les athlètes olympiques que vous avez rencontrés)</string>
```
The problem? It seems that the thing that lays out text in android only respects `\n` and not actual line breaks, which means that the dashes that supposed to be list bullets appear _mid-line_.

Live example (using a different string, because it looks worse): https://i.imgur.com/SYYvbU7.png

Since translations come from https://translatewiki.net, it could be a problem on their side, but it may be easy to work around this for now.

title: i18n guidelines about plurals say "Always include %d in "one"
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="bug"), Label(name="localization")]
body:
Here's the important part from https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/string-resource.html#Plurals (first example for Plurals section)

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<resources>
    <plurals name="numberOfSongsAvailable">
        <!--
             As a developer, you should always supply "one" and "other"
             strings. Your translators will know which strings are actually
             needed for their language. Always include %d in "one" because
             translators will need to use %d for languages where "one"
             doesn't mean 1 (as explained above).
          -->
        <item quantity="one">%d song found.</item>
        <item quantity="other">%d songs found.</item>
    </plurals>
</resources>
```

Here's what this project's strings.xml has:

```
  <plurals name="uploads_pending_notification_indicator">
    <item quantity="one">1 file uploading</item>
    <item quantity="other">%d files uploading</item>
  </plurals>
```

I don't know much about android i18n, but this looks contrary to the guidelines.

title: Update values-ru/strings.xml
body:
Typos, punctuation and style fixes.

I noticed that translations come from translatewiki too late. So if PRs like this are fine -- great, if not -- I could probably redo it on the wiki.

title: Add a privacy statement
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="privacy"), Label(name="question")]
body:
With the Nearby feature using queries sent to Wikidata, (#289) I believe we have privacy issues to consider, for example the accidental disclosure of sensitive locations of the user (e.g. home address).

In my opinion, we should make sure that users are aware of the fact that:

1. the app may disclose the current location of the user's device to the Wikidata server when querying nearby places. <s>(And maybe explicitly ask the user to agree with the Terms of Use of the WMF?)</s>
2. the app may disclose the current location of the user's the device to the core app developers subscribed to the private mailing list when sending crash reports. (I believe the current app doesn't include coordinates to an error message, but it may happen in future.)

For developers, I would imagine something like:

1. Developers may use personal information obtained from the user only for the purpose of improving this app.
2. Developers may not disclose personal information obtained from the user.

I'm not sure in what way we want to deliver such a statement to the user. Maybe a wiki page and a link from the About screen to it? A dialog before a relevant action (e.g. sending a query) is done?

title: Make refresh icon for nearby places white (closes #483)
body:
**Old**

title: Use Timber for logging
body:
Closes #486.

Note that this still logs all calls in release builds. This behaviour can be changed through the use of a custom Tree ([example](https://github.com/JakeWharton/timber/blob/master/timber-sample/src/main/java/com/example/timber/ExampleApp.java)). I didn't include this as I felt that it was out of the scope of the PR.

title: Measuring contributors who have never contributed to Commons before
label: [Label(name="IEG"), Label(name="question")]
body:
When I wrote the "measures of success" for my [IEG grant proposal](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Grants:IEG/Improve_%27Upload_to_Commons%27_Android_App) last year, one of them was "10+ new contributors who have never contributed to Commons before". Clearly I did not think that through very well, haha, since I still have no idea how this could possibly be measured. :/ It would definitely need to be measured on the WMF side since we should not collect such data via the app.

Even worse, the next measure of success that I suggested was "Less than 10% of pictures uploaded by new users (who have never contributed to Wikimedia before) are unusable". Not only is this dependent on us being able to do the former item, it is also dependent on us having knowledge of which accounts exactly are new. I understand that we can check the contributions of every user tagged under "Uploaded with Mobile Android app", but with 2000+ active users now, that is not going to be a trivial undertaking (I wrote the proposal when we had 200 active users).

Any idea if there is any way I can do such a thing, or at least something close to it?

title: Apply the user's second preferred language to place labels (for API level 24 or higher)
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="localization"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
Currently the names of nearby places are shown in random languages when the particular item has no label in the language of the user's first preference.  If the user speaks another language, we should try to find labels in it. It appears that Android 7 has [LocaleList.getDefault](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/multilingual-support.html) to enable this.

For example, when Wikidata doesn't have a label in Japanese (my first language) I would like to see it in English (my second language) which tends to have a wider coverage.

Ideally this should extend to third, fourth, etc, but supporting two would already be a great improvement.

title: Versioning and changelog for v2.2.2 release
On-the-go notifications for Nearby photo opportunities
body:
_(please change the title for a more meaningful one)_
This is an idea that is worth taking note of but I know it would require some thinking and possibly a lot of programming. It would be cool if I could receive notifications when walking around a city when I get close to an object that needs a picture. The app would notify me of the object and ask me to upload it, with a correct Q item number serving as the basis for the description (and possibly also P373 for the appropriate category).

Someone suggested that we limit the number of uploads that we show in the main screen, to help with the OutOfMemoryError encountered by those running slower phones. I think he has a point, and there are quite a few others who are encountering the same issue.

IMO we should set the default to something like the last 10 uploads, and maybe have an option in Settings for the user to select to view more if they want to.

title: Versioning and changelog for v2.2 release
Add "Up navigation" for Settings activity
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body: There is currently no up navigation (the button on the left of the action bar that lets you tap to go "back" to the main activity) in Settings.

title: "Use previous title/description" should be disabled for first upload
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly")]
body:
Showing the "Use previous title/description" button to a completely new user can be confusing.

I think it should be made invisible or a gray button that doesn't work, before the first upload is made.

title: Show an alert when no Nearby result is found
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="nearby")]
body: Nearby may be empty when nothing exists around or data retrieval fails for network errors. Currently it results in an empty Nearby screen, which may confuse the user. A simple alert (maybe a Toast) saying something like "No results - please try again later" would solve this.

title: Should tutorial be displayed with each reinstallation of the app, or only once?
label: [Label(name="question")]

title: Define a custom TextView that displays HTML
body: This makes the layout file `activity_about.xml` more declarative as we are defining that Html text is going to be displayed. This also modularises the Html TextView's as we aren't defining the behaviour in `AboutActivity`.

title: Bigger text fields for title/description
label: [Label(name="UX - user experience"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
How about two lines for title, four lines for description?

Let's make life easier for people who are patient enough to enter a lot of info.

Most of my titles take two lines, and it is a pain to not see the beginning of my text. When line wraps I often wonder whether the beginning is lost.

title: Add ActionBar to About screen
body:
Before

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6900601/25015840/74268a5c-2075-11e7-9f08-448b147188c1.png)

After

![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6900601/25014635/7c78acbc-2070-11e7-805b-092c20986610.png)

title: Switch Nearby to Wikidata Query
body:
Fixes #289 partially - not a full migration but a first step. Wikidata-based results seem to be less accurate - it sometimes suggests articles with images on Wikipedia pages (but without an image *on Wikidata*). I think further filtering is necessary.

This may fix #485 too. (It works for me, but please test.)

title: Fix Nearby GPS issue by reverting merge
body:
Fix #485 .

This reverts commit 397f7dbc85a0761485fbcb8fbdbd6e595f2c54ca, reversing
changes made to ce994c4f3e684b0c8391fe2ad02d9b67769a24e0.

title: Disable ACRA on debug builds
body: Per #491

title: Skip CSV header outside of while loop
body: Considering we know that the variable `firstLine` is only true on the first pass of the while loop, we are able to take it out of the while loop. As the while loop is very expensive, iterating over hundreds of thousand of times, it seems redundant to do such a comparison (i.e. `if (firstLine)`) that many times when the outcome is deterministic and easy to write.

title: Reduce scope of places field
Use one networking library
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="question")]
body:
Currently both Volley and Apache HttpClient are being used. I think it'd be preferable to just use one networking library. My suggestion would not be to use either Volley or Apache HttpClient though, but instead use [Retrofit](https://github.com/square/retrofit), mainly because:
* it is used a lot more than Volley is
* there is a [GSON converter](https://github.com/square/retrofit/tree/master/retrofit-converters/gson) which makes JSON parsing a breeze
* there is better documentation on Retrofit compared to Volley
* it is more modular than Volley or Apache HttpClient with the use of converters and adapters (though it has been a while since I've used Volley or Apache HttpClient so correct me if I'm wrong).

Thoughts?

title: Turn off ACRA for debug builds
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body: I don't get any stack trace of exceptions caused by the app, but instead I get the ACRA dialog stating that the app has crashed. This usually leads me to commenting out the ACRA initialisation in `CommonsApplication`. Wouldn't it be better to turn off ACRA when doing a debug build and turn it on for release builds?

title: Fix format parameters for strings
Use getString(…) with formatArgs
body: Doing so allows Android to pass the locale into `String.format(…)` for us, as evident by the source code `Resources#getString(int, Object...)`.

title: Delete all branches that aren't master
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
It seems that all the branches that aren't master aren't being maintained and are very old, ranging from a year to 4 years old. Looking over the commits of each branch, it doesn't appear we would be losing anything as some of them have no commits, and the rest don't appear to have gotten very far in respect to the branches desire.

Keeping all these branches gives the false sense that a lot of parallel work is being done in this project when none is. Also, in the future, if any parallel work is to be done, then it won't be masked by all the current unmaintained branches.

title: Update Quadtree dependency
body: Exclusion of transitive dependency no longer required as noted at Quadtree-org/Quadtree#2.

title: Use Timber for logging
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
https://github.com/JakeWharton/timber

This was suggested by @maskaravivek and @veyndan at #485 . At a quick glance, it looks good to me (although I had no idea you should apparently not log in production?). What do you guys think?

title: Pre-release Nearby does not detect location
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="pre-release")]
body:
The pre-release version of Nearby (current master branch) loads the CSV, but does not detect your location when used in a freshly-installed app. Tested on an API 24 real device (Samsung Galaxy S7). The released version works fine (tested on the same night).

Might have something to do with location permissions not being asked? Not sure, will have to test further. @maskaravivek , what do you think could have broken it?

title: Tapping 'refresh' icon before Nearby list has loaded prevents it from ever loading
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="nearby")]
body: If I tap 'refresh' before the list has loaded, it will never load. Tapping a second time later, or leaving and returning to the activity, does not fix the problem.

title: Refresh icon color out of place
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
As seen below, the refresh icon in the Nearby Places screen is an odd grey. I'm thinking it might look better as white, similar to the other icons?

 ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Commons_Android_app_Nearby_Places_feature.png/337px-Commons_Android_app_Nearby_Places_feature.png)

title: Refactored NearbyActivity to extract out reusable code outside of the activity
body:
Have refactored the `NearbyActivity` and `NearbyListFragment` to make it a lot cleaner. 

- Moved out length/distance calculation utils methods to `LengthUtils`
- Create `ResourceUtils` for getting appropriate icon resource based on `Place` description 
- Created `NearbyAdapter` and `NearbyViewHolder` outside of the activity class. This way it can be used in other activities too in the future. 
- Started [using Butterknife](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/wiki/Code-Style) for the view bindings.
- Created `LocationServiceManager` to fetch location. This would enable its usage in other places as well. 

Have tested that the Nearby Places page works as expected.

title: Refactored welcome activity to decouple the view pager
body:
Have refactored the Welcome activity 

1. To decouple the code for view pager adapter.
2. Start using [butterknife for view bindings](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/wiki/Code-Style).

title: Remove duplicate code in SettingsActivity
body: Noticed this duplicate code while browsing the codebase.

title: Fixes #435: Allowing state loss commit for fragment transaction
body:
Fixes #435. There could be several approaches for fixing the crash but in our case simply allowing `commitAllowingStateLoss` should be good enough. Feel free to take a look at these links [1](https://medium.com/inloop/demystifying-androids-commitallowingstateloss-cb9011a544cc)[2](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14860239/checking-if-state-is-saved-before-committing-a-fragmenttransaction) for this fix. 

Also the [article](http://www.androiddesignpatterns.com/2013/08/fragment-transaction-commit-state-loss.html) explaining various use cases is also a good read. 

If the user puts the app in background after selecting a picture(either from gallery or clicking from camera) then ideally we should not commit the `SingleUploadFragment` fragment transaction. Its acceptable for us to allow for state loss rather than crashing the app.

title: Create SettingsFragment
body:
Part of #455

Next is SingleUploadFragment spinner & Utils, and WelcomeActivity. Might find a way to not require a context in Utils, we'll see.

Tested in API 25, 23, 21, 15 (emulators), and API 24 (Samsung Galaxy S6). I noticed the checkboxes are a [bit weird styled](http://imgur.com/a/6tW47) in API 15 but it is present in the current version so this is not a change I have introduced.

EDIT - Codacy always hates me - I've only added 1 of the 4 'issues', which is a line that is 101 characters instead of 100 that can't really be avoided sensibly.

title: Use parameterized types
Remove unnecessary super call
Don't have default values when obtaining item from spinner
body: A spinner by definition has only one item selected, so if it is not one of those items an exception should be thrown. That's why this PR removes default values when getting the string from the spinner as this can easily be a source of bugs if a license is ever added to the spinner.

title: Fixed URL
Tell users to localize the app
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="localization")]
body: At least link from About.

title: Remove TODOs about being an auto-generated method stub
Remove unused classes
body: Unused and have been for a while - unless anyone objects I think there's no point keeping them.

title: People not pressing the floppy icon after selecting categories
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
Especially with the new futuristic floppy icon, I am afraid that many people will select categories and then press Back, without thinking they have to press the floppy icon. This is a loss of time for them and a loss of metadata for Commons. How can we improve things?

Idea 1: Add icons in real time. As soon as the user taps a checkbox, send a request to Commons to add the category. I believe it is the safest to get all categories, but it may be hard to implement. We must also remove categories that the user unchecks.

Idea 2: Auto-upload categories when the user switches to another app or presses back.

Idea 3: If the user presses Back, tell them that they must press that floppy icon first. If the user switches to another app, or even reboot their phone, show that same category activity with the same "Press that floppy!" indication when they start the app again. (Auto-save the state the user is in. That concept could be useful in the description activity as well: Chose a pic, start entering a description, phone crashes, reboot and restart the app: You can continue to enter the end of the description like nothing happened)

Right now I would vote for Idea 3, what do you think? Don't hesitate to post other ideas.

title: Remove AsyncTask utility methods
body: As `Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= Build.VERSION_CODES.HONEYCOMB` is always true [here](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/compare/master...veyndan:async-util?expand=1#diff-ead409481556059dfc80428578e29a4bL132) and [here](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/compare/master...veyndan:async-util?expand=1#diff-ead409481556059dfc80428578e29a4bL143), these utility methods are no longer needed as it has become an unnecessary abstraction.

title: Remove unused method implode(…)
body:
I found this kind of funny how long a truly useless piece of code could last for.

This method was added in 4df8ec8fa940c0ff7f7a999379bb29b17064f4a3 but was never used in that commit nor can I find a single usage of the method in the 3.5 years it's been there.

Also I tested it and it doesn't seem to of ever worked correctly anyway. The output of doing `implode(",", Arrays.asList("a", "b", "c"))` is `"[a, b, c],[a, b, c],[a, b, c]"` when it should be `"a,b,c"`. This is due to [this line](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/b4231bbfdc967faf5c83eb44104c9f23bfce57e8/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/Utils.java#L204) where the argument should have been `piece` instead of `pieces`. 

The functionality of this method is identical to that of `TextUtils.join(…)` so this is (and always has been) a pointless method.

title: Use generated version name
body:
The method denoted in this PR is cleaner than the way it is currently implemented, and also any concern of the race condition of `APPLICATION_VERSION` (noted [here](https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/blob/master/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/CommonsApplication.java#L55)) is removed.

The method used in this PR is described [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/21119027/3424405) whereas the current implementation is described [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/6593822/3424405).

Note that defining the `versionCode` and `versionName` in `build.gradle` is logically equivalent to defining it in `AndroidManifest.xml` (as described [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/32138560/3424405)). It is necessary to define these attributes in `build.gradle` as the `BuildConfig` constants wouldn't be generated otherwise.

title: Place Feedback menu item below Settings
Disabling LineLength Codacy check?
label: [Label(name="debated"), Label(name="discussion")]
body:
Personally, I prefer longer lines to weirdly broken up ones and don't see a point raising a load of [LineLength errors](http://checkstyle.sourceforge.net/config_sizes.html#LineLength) with Codacy if it works, is understandable and Android Studio has horizontal scrolling and smart word wrap built in.

Thoughts?

title: Don't show icon in ActionBar overflow
body: As per discussion in #442.

title: Nearby: show class icon
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="question")]
body:
There are icons for: bus station, university, school, religious edifice, etc.
On the nearby map, show icon of the Wikidata class of the item.
Shown on a map or list, it would allow to quickly decide what nearby items to go for.
For instance, I could choose to avoid schools as it could be seen as creepy to go take pictures on a school day, and rather focus on statues.

title: Code walkthrough for new devs
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly")]
body:
I was looking back through my old notes on the app, and found some that I wrote when I was getting to know the codebase. They are very informal and possibly not 100% technically accurate, but I wondered if they might be helpful to a new contributor. I know the Readme has some basic information, but it doesn't really go in depth into the working of the app (nor should it, otherwise it would be too long).

I copied my old notes into this wiki: https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/wiki/Code-walkthrough-for-new-devs-(draft) . If anyone is interested, please feel free to read, modify, etc.

title: Versioning and changelog for v2.1 release
Lower target SDK to 23
body: Temporary solution for #457

title: Refactor ShareActivity.java
label: [Label(name="assigned"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Unfortunately, ShareActivity is currently a big jumble of spaghetti code, haha. :/ It was already huge when we inherited the legacy app, but the complexity increased when I added to it during my newbie days as an Outreachy intern, and then again after we targeted API 23 and added runtime permissions checking.

I think ideally we would want to separate as much of the logic as possible into new classes - one for checking image coordinates, caching them, and initiating the calls to MediaWiki API for nearby categories; one for Uri handling; one for permissions if possible (not sure if possible since permissions require dialogs and thus access to the UI?)... and keep as little logic as possible in ShareActivity.java so that it is used mainly for interface code.

Not an easy undertaking, but it would be very appreciated if anyone wants to try. :)

title: Fix Codacy Issues
Update preferences
body:
Use `PreferenceFragment`, easier to maintain preferences, recommended way of doing it in API level > 11 (our minSdkVersion is 15). Also have updated SingleUploadFragment and Utils to work better, and use new arrays.xml.

I think the most controversial change is requiring Utils helper methods to be passed a context. This is to access the strings so we don't duplicate stuff e.g. creating `Licenses` in `Prefs.java` - there's already so many similar string names, we don't need more!

As this is quite a big change affecting a large number of files I think it's best if it is approved by at least 2 people before it's merged.

A quick explanation of what I've done:
- Removed `Licenses` constant in Prefs, prefer using `arrays.xml` (which in turn inherits from `strings.xml`)
- Move most of the code in SettingsActivity into SettingsFragment, and remove code no longer needed to force an ActionBar
- setOnPreferenceChangeListener's on the spinner to update the summary as before, and recreate the activity to update the theme straight away when changed
- Tidy up Utils, remove code blocks for API levels < 11 (current minSdkVersion is 15)
- Require context to be passed to Utils to compare strings
- Update SingleUploadFragment to not duplicate values again, use `arrays.xml` instead (which in turn inherits from `strings.xml`). May be an idea to move large if block getting license shorthand from name from SingleUploadFragment to Utils.
- Move "Become a beta tester" link in settings to bottom

Please do ask any questions about anything else, will either help spot potential bugs or you'll be able to maintain it easier later :)

title: Issues with new theme
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="pre-release")]
body:
@domdomegg @neslihanturan @maskaravivek I've been doing more in-depth testing before releasing the new version (on a Nexus S emulator API 23 and 25, prior to real device testing), and a few things that I noticed with the new themes/icons:

1. When sent to the overflow menu due to the action bar being full, "From gallery" shows up with its icon on the left. Besides being the only item in the overflow menu with an icon, when the light theme is selected, the icon isn't visible due to being white.

![gallery](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3611199/24091641/027a846e-0d95-11e7-8151-80d50df47166.png)

2. The subtext in the tutorial is black now, while the text is white. IMO keeping the text and subtext roughly the same color is a lot more aesthetic.

![tutorial2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3611199/24091768/d9ce91da-0d95-11e7-8a44-5d0855d0d210.png)

3. I think it might be a good idea to make the dark theme the default instead of the light theme, so that people start out with the theme that they are used to, and have the option to change it if they prefer light. What do you guys think?

4. Very minor issue, and could just be a personal preference, but in the media details pane, landscape images have a large white band above them. IMO this looks okay in the dark theme, but rather jarring in the light theme. 

![media details](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3611199/24091755/bfba3bbe-0d95-11e7-9f53-7d8548d9bdd3.png)

title: Make Checkstyle and/or PMD work on Codacy/Codecov
body:
Codacy is supposed to send Checkstyle results to pull requests. However, it seems that Codacy doesn't work with our checkstyle.xml well and doesn't deliver those results. (See https://www.codacy.com/app/commons-app/apps-android-commons/dashboard?bid=4271658 - there should be far more than 3 issues.) What seemed to have worked previously (#386) was [PMD](https://pmd.github.io/) contained in the default setting of Codacy. 

I asked the Codacy support about it, and they told me that their developers will investigate why it fails.

Because the investigation might take a long time, I'm looking into alternative checkers that work well with Codacy, such as PMD. Even if the resolution is quicker than I thought, another tool won't be bad to have.

title: Alternative solution to view binding other than ButterKnife
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
Disclaimer: this is a copy-paste from #395 as it seems that I was late to the discussion and I feel that my points warranted a separate issue.

One problem with using Butterknife (though minor) is that the fields must be at least package-private, which means the scope is unnecessarily broad in some circumstances.

An alternative that I am currently using in one of my projects is to use the generated view binder found using the data binding. Using this doesn't mean that you have to use any of the features of the data binding library (nor would I advocate for such a thing). The main benefit that I found using the generated view binder is that it is type safe, something that neither Butterknife nor the standard Android `findViewById` offers i.e. you don't have to cast the `findViewById` to a subclass of `View`.

Jake Wharton (the writer of Butterknife) even says that the use of it can be advantageous ([source](https://www.reddit.com/r/androiddev/comments/54ug8h/no_more_findviewbyid_if_you_havent_started_using/d85uoec/)). [Here](https://medium.com/google-developers/no-more-findviewbyid-457457644885#.evq9g4cul)'s an article which tells you basically all that you need to know about this approach. 

I thought I'd just add this to the discussion as it doesn't get talked about much, but would reduce the boilerplate code even more than that of Butterknife alone, is type safe, and IIRC `findViewById` traverses the layout at runtime whereas using the view binding aspect of databinding, view processing is done at compilation time.

title: Fix lint issues
body: Fix some lint issues at #171

title: Place placeholder strings in separate strings xml file
body:
This was mostly inspired by the way the [Google IO App](https://github.com/google/iosched/blob/2016/android/src/debug/res/values/placeholder_strings.xml) handles placeholder strings.

Some benefits that I can think of of this are:

1. Makes strings separate from layout file
2. If you want to see other languages in the layout editor, then adding new languages will be the same as usual (except adding it to `debug/res` instead of `main/res`). This means that the source code of the layout doesn't have to constantly be changed to see the effect of a different language (e.g. English which is written from left to right would look different from Hebrew which is written right to left) but the language settings can be modified from the layout editor instead.

Note that I have strayed slightly from the Google IO App's implementation of this by omitting `translatable=false` from the string resources values in `placeholder_strings.xml` due to point no. 2 listed above.

title: Up-for-grabs, awesome-for-beginners and others
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly")]
body:
Could be a good idea to add this repo to lists to get some more contributors on the team.

Many lists require a tag for beginners and the new <s>`for beginners`</s> `beginner friendly` one could be quite good - we might need some more issues though for beginners to try though!

title: Update gradle
body:
Updated gradle build tools to 2.3.0, updated android support libs to v25.2, updated targetSdkVersion to 25. Removed unused ndk libs, code that required it was removed several months ago.

More info in #381 

Also was having a look at some of the other libs and had some questions:
1. On every gradle build I get: 
    ```
    WARNING: Dependency org.apache.httpcomponents:httpclient:4.2.2 is ignored for release as it may be conflicting with the internal version provided by Android.
   ```
   and I'm not sure when it comes from. It seems unrelated to the `org.apache.http.legacy` lib on line 29, as removing that line makes no change. Doesn't seem to be doing anything bad, just might be something that might be adding bulk to the app for no reason.

2. Do we still need to be using the old version of GSON? See #410

title: Update GSON?

Having tested quite a few images I can't find anything wrong with using the latest version of GSON (2.7) for this (in build.gradle we're using 1.4) - can't remember exactly why I said the old version solved something.

I was thinking though, it seems a bit of a waste of resources to bring in a whole library just to decode one string, especially when we know it only comes in one format.

The other thing was I saw in ShareActivity `getFileMetadata` seems to be called unnecessarily a lot - will have to look into it later (and possibly refactor ShareActivity).

title: Added support for butterknife library for view bindings
body: As per the discussion in #395 have added support for Butterknife. Have refactored a few existing fragments to start using Butterknife. Have tested the existing functionality and it seems to be working as expected. Will come up with the wiki doc for using it in the codebase by this weekend.

title: Fixes #405: Add some spacing on the About view
body:
Have added 12dp left and right margins. 

![about_view](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3069373/23718954/7eb45972-045f-11e7-86e1-d64989676500.png)

title: Thoughts on workflow proposal?
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
Now that we have more active devs, @nicolas-raoul has posted a suggestion at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/commons-app-android/vXlvbV2PZRY/8bOYHpusAAAJ regarding a proposed workflow for the team. Please chime in and let us know what you think. :) @domdomegg @veyndan and @maskaravivek , we would appreciate your thoughts in particular. If everyone is on board with it, we might try to start implementing within the next week or so.

(This will only apply to the app repo, it is entirely up to @tobias47n9e if he wants to do the same for the website repo, since there are fewer active devs there.)

title: Use LinearLayouts instead of unnecessary RelativeLayouts
body: Slight performance benefit, simplify the layout a bit as per @veyndan's comment in #388

title: Add some spacing on the "About" view
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
On my phone there is no space between the text and the edge of the screen. I would be nice to have the usual 5 to 20px left and right. Might be a good issue for a new contributor. Do we have a tag for that?

![screenshot_2017-03-07-17-16-41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6953323/23671224/bdcdc558-036a-11e7-8666-9c3c8c448ffb.png)

title: Versioning and changelog for release v2.0
Beta testing?
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="high priority"), Label(name="question")]
body: Now that we have >2000 active installs, I'm wondering if we should consider some form of beta testing to reduce the chances of us pushing broken code in a release. What do you guys think, would it be useful or should we not bother until we have more active users? If it's a good idea, how should the beta testing be carried out?

title: Remove references to icons when showAsAction is set to never
body: Even though there isn't currently any noticeable overhead in referencing system icons, when implementing #380 there is no point of including these extra icons in the APK if they are never going to be used (as references to system icons will be replaced with references to local drawables which of course will have to be added to the APK).

title: Use GridLayout to show grid of Images instead of RelativeLayout
Remove unused TextView's
[WIP] testing bad code - do not merge this
[WIP] testing bad code with codacy - do not merge this
"Wikimedia Commons" as a trademark must remain in English
label: [Label(name="beginner friendly"), Label(name="localization")]
body:
Hi,

I was translating this app at translatewiki.net and noticed the "about license" string, which says:
```
Wikimedia Commons and its logo are trademarks of the Wikimedia Foundation and are used with the permission of the Wikimedia Foundation.
```

The problem with this is that "Wikimedia Commons" has pretty different names in some languages, for example _Vikisklad_ (Викисклад) in Russian or _Vikishituf_ (ויקישיתוף) in Hebrew, but only the original English name is an actual trademark.

I added a note about it to the message documentation (qq), but to avoid confusing translators, it shouldn't appear in the string at all, but be inserted using a parameter (like %1$s).

Thank you!

title: [WIP] testing bad code
Refactoring: Using Butterknife for Android views and callbacks to fields and methods
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
In my opinion we should start using [Butterknife](https://github.com/JakeWharton/butterknife) in the app to make the code look more readable. Atleast support for it can be added and any new views can be referenced using Butterknife. Gradually the rest of the codebase can be refactored to start using it. Am suggesting its usage because of the following reasons:
- will make the code look more readable 
- will eliminate a lot of boilerplate code
- its better to perform this exercise before the codebase starts getting bigger

Looking forward to opinions from others as well. @misaochan @nicolas-raoul

title: Check for external storage permission before downloading
body:
Cause otherwise we would get massive painful conflicts, this incudes #391 - check and merge that one first!

Fixes #393

title: Existing file check algorithm uses SHA1 encryption
label: [Label(name="upstream")]
body: `ShareActivity` uses `getSHA1` method of `Utils` class to generate SHA1 of file from input stream. Given the vulnerabilities exposed with SHA1(not sure how critical it is in our use case) we should consider moving to SHA2 for our file matching algorithms. Both the server and client will have to incorporate these changes if we go forward with it.

body: The diamond operator support was added at [build tools 19](http://stackoverflow.com/a/19470405/3424405).

title: Replace fully qualified names with imports
Add Checkstyle support
body:
Closes #359.

Google's default Checkstyle uses two spaces instead of 4, so this was the only modification to the `checkstyle.xml`. Modification and the source of the `checkstyle.xml` is noted at the top of the file.

An HTML report is produced at `build/reports/checkstyle/checkstyle.html` when the `checkstyle` Gradle task is run. As `check` is set to depend on `checkstyle`, running `check` also runs this task. This means that Travis will now run Checkstyle as Travis runs the `check` Gradle task.

The Java code hasn't been reformatted to respect the Checkstyle rules, so a lot of errors should occur (`1108` at this time of build).

Use Checkstyle for travis-CI

I saw that it was mentioned in passing on #24 but nothing seemed to come of it. As Travis-CI is now in use since that issue, I feel it would be beneficial to reconsider the use of Checkstyle as Checkstyle would then be run against every PR. My suggestion would to use Google's coding standard as it is one of the more popular ones.

I'd be happy to work on this but just want some confirmation that such a change is desired.

title: Versioning and changelog for v1.43 release
Fix new-line formatting in tutorial screens
Add missing @Override annotations
Make the theme extend from the material theme instead of holo
body:
The `styles.xml` in `values-v9` is redundant as the `@style/ProgressBar` is always being overridden by the `@style/ProgressBar` defined in `values-v14/styles.xml`. Hence I could safely delete `values-v9/styles.xml` without affecting the behaviour of the app.

Defining a `values-v14/styles.xml` is unnecessary as the `minSdk` is `15` so the styles in that file would always have been used over that of `values/styles.xml`. So I moved those styles to `values/styles.xml` and set the parent to the AppCompat's material theme. As it was already set for `@style/AppTheme`, is was only necessary to modify the `@style/ProgressBar` parent.

title: Replace fill_parent with match_parent
body: `fill_parent` has been deprecated since API Level 8 and has been replaced with `match_parent`. This PR reflects those changes.

title: Selection of topics for Vienna hackathon and Prague pre-hackathon
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby")]
body:
As the events are drawing nearer, I am attempting to consolidate the suggestions offered at #293 so that we can make a decision. The [Prague pre-hackathon](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikimedia_Hackathon_2017/Prehackathon_Prague), based on my discussions with @VojtechDostal, would involve an introduction to the app to familiarize people with the codebase, and a small task related to the Nearby function. The [Vienna hackathon](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Wikimedia_Hackathon_2017) would likely involve a larger task and would also provide an opportunity to collaborate with other WMF folks (e.g. newcomers, or the Wikipedia app devs) if needed.

**Potential tasks, in my opinion, based on suggestions received:**

Pre-hackathon:

- Displaying the Nearby results on a map
- Requesting Nearby images provided by the web-app that @tobias47n9e is working on
- Switching to a Wikidata query for Nearby results

Hackathon:

- Any of the tasks mentioned above
- Collaborating with other WMF developers to share knowledge and discuss how to reduce technical debt and other stalled issues (@whym has talked to Rachel Farrand and received encouraging feedback on this)
-  Recruiting and onboarding new contributors to the Commons app, especially those who are signing up as mentees for the hackathon

Thoughts?

title: all-caps must not be used for emphasis
label: [Label(name="localization"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
Capital letters can be used only in a small number of scripts. They don't exist in Arabic, Hindi, Georgian, Chinese, and most other languages.

Because of this, relying only on all-caps, as in "Please do NOT upload" makes it impossible to translate the emphasis into languages that don't have capital letters.

The emphasis must be added using some other design method.

title: Rephrase title/desc without slash
body: This looks more natural in English.

title: Rephrase bug reports and suggestions without slash
body: This looks more natural in English.

title: zero quantity in messages doesn't work in English
label: [Label(name="localization")]
body:
Hi,

I've been translating the app into Hebrew at translatewiki. I didn't actually try running yet, so this whole issue might be wrong, but I'm pretty sure that the "zero" quantity in English plurals doesn't work. The quantity identifiers for different languages are based on their grammar, and since zero in English is the same as "other" (i.e. anything other than "one"), "zero" is not a valid string for English.

Furthermore, translatable strings Android apps don't support specific quantities, like MediaWiki does (again, this is AFAIK, and I might be wrong—I'm not an Android expert).

The only string that I find with "zero" at the moment is contributions_subtitle.

To make it actually work as intended, it probably has to be rewritten with a condition.

title: Remove unnecessary whitespace from an English translatable string
Rephrase a translatable string without comma splice
Changing main activity to list/map of nearby places that need photos (far future)
label: [Label(name="gallery"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="question")]
body:
Currently the main activity is a list of the user's past uploads, with the upload, camera, and nearby functions relegated to small icons on the ActionBar (and that is in the best case scenario with a wide screen - on small phones some of them are in the overflow menu). It looks pretty, but I wonder if that is the best use of main screen real estate?

In the far future (after the Nearby feature has been suitably improved), what do you think of changing the main activity to a list/map of nearby places that need photos, with the upload and camera buttons taking up a more prominent location on the main screen? The current list of past uploads could still exist, but instead would be accessible via the ActionBar (or a nav drawer if we get around to that).

This would be a pretty big change though, so I am hesitant to propose it without strong userbase support.

Anyone have any thoughts on this?

title: Create Youtube video to be placed on Play Store
label: [Label(name="publicity"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
Splitting this task from #86 . For reference, we want to create a Youtube video showing how to use our app, and have it placed on our Google Play Store.

Some thoughts/questions:

1. What exactly do we want to demonstrate in the video? My thoughts:
  - Upload gallery pics from within the app
  - Upload pics directly from gallery (via Share)
  - Upload pic taken by in-app camera
  - Enabling geotagging and changing licenses in Settings (maybe?)
  - Nearby function (maybe?)
2. Should we create a new Youtube account just for the video?
3. How should we do the narration? I've never made a video before, so I have no experience of this. Do we take the video first and then try to match narration to it, or narrate while taking the video? How do we make it look not-too-amateurish? Should we consider asking for help to make it look/sound more professional?

Just a wild idea, looking forward to your feedback about it:
How about putting a "List of recently featured images" at the top of the gallery? Scrollable to the left/right.

Plus:

title: Provide explicit selection of licenses when uploading image
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="licenses")]
body:
I've received feedback from a few users (on Google Play and on Commons) that they did not like not being able to select the license when uploading. Users can currently select a license in Settings, but this isn't very clear.

Thoughts on putting a license selection field in the title/desc screen?

title: Only start image upload after categories have been selected?
label: [Label(name="categorization"), Label(name="question")]
body:
Currently, categories aren't submitted with the original file but are submitted as a modification later - this is because uploading starts immediately when the picture is selected, whereas categories are selected after that.

There are 2 issues with this:
1) The modification sometimes doesn't go through (see #310 ). A few of my recent uploads, such as https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Old_building_near_Beverly_Hills_Park.jpg , suffer from this, and other people have complained about it too
2) It might be confusing to new users. For instance, this comment:

> But apart from that, the workflow didn't feel natural. When you start, it is hard to understand what was going on. At some point I think I was seeing new images being uploaded? And without being asked for a license, whether I took the photo myself or anything, or to confirm anything, the image was suddenly uploaded (even before the category selection, which was apparently added in a later edit) - which I only noticed because it was the top image on the 'recently uploaded' flow. Quite a confusing experience.

What do you guys think? The web-based Upload Wizard only starts uploads after categories are selected, and aside from it taking just a bit more time, there don't seem to be any significant drawbacks to waiting.

title: Raising awareness of the difference between this app and the deprecated mobile web app
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/2016_Community_Wishlist_Survey/Categories/Commons#Uploading_from_a_mobile_phone - This is about the 6th time I have encountered mention of the copyvio/selfie-pocalypse of 2014 when our app is brought up. :/

Is there any way we can raise awareness of the Commons community in general about the differences between the deprecated mobile website (which was associated with the copyvio/selfie-pocalypse) and the Android app (which was not)? I have been explaining the difference each time I see it being brought up, as well as linking http://tools.wmflabs.org/commons-app-stats/ , but it doesn't seem to be very effective. The various small discussions are clearly not reaching the community as a whole, as many people are still mistakenly equating the two. 

Any suggestions? I think this is pretty important, because we need the support of the Commons community if we want to make progress with this app.

title: Improve title-based category search
label: [Label(name="categorization"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
1. Chose picture
2. Entered file name "Nintendo sign at Tokyo branch in Taito"
3. The proposed categories did not contain anything related to Nintendo nor Taito.
4. Waiting some time does not change the proposed categories

That's because the API searches for "Nintendo sign at Tokyo branch in Taito" instead of "Nintendo" and "sign" and "Tokyo" and "branch" and "Taito".

We would need to split into words, then remove grammar words such as "the is first to into" or more generally all small words, then perform a search for each seemingly relevant word (these seem to be called [stop words](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stop_words))
It is less easy for languages without spaces (like Japanese), but most file names are in space-separated languages so for now that's not a big problem.

A bigger problem is that most titles are not in English, which means we would have to first guess the language, and then extract stop words in the context of that language. To not make the app to big, we could write a multi-languages extractor (for instance using [nltk](http://stackoverflow.com/a/19133088/226958)) and host it on a Wikimedia server.

title: Switch to Wikidata in addition instead of wiki-needs-pictures
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="nearby"), Label(name="question")]
body:
I started to wonder whether we should use Wikidata instead of wiki-needs-pictures.

Advantages of Wikidata:
- Real-time. Add a picture to the item, and it disappears from the map immediately. wiki-needs-pictures is only updated once a week.
- Fast: In my tests the WikiData request takes about 2 seconds (even in an area with many items needing pictures), compared with wiki-needs-pictures' 17 seconds on the same network connection.
- Data plan-friendly: Wikidata uses only a few kilobytes, whereas wiki-needs-pictures downloads a file of several megabytes every time the app is started. This is thanks to WikiData has out-of-the-box area queries. Implementing area queries for wiki-needs-pictures would require a lot of development and a good server.
- Memory-friendly: Not having to keep this multimegabytes file in memory.
- Works for all Wikipedias, unlike wiki-needs-pictures which needs custom code for each Wikipedia (I added that code for the Japanese Wikipedia)

Advantages of wiki-needs-pictures:
- Listed pictures really need someone to go there and take a picture (whereas on Wikidata most missing pictures are actually available on Commons and just not linked yet, see [WDFIST](https://tools.wmflabs.org/fist/wdfist/?wdq=AROUND[625,35.66262,139.73060,2]&depth=3&language=en&project=wikipedia&no_images_only=1&prefilled=1)).
- Special requests may be implemented in the future. For instance: there are are already pictures of this temple's exterior, but a picture of the inside is needed.

---

All of the API requests we need (and more) can be found in the new WikiShootMe: https://tools.wmflabs.org/wikishootme/

When [this WDFIST issue](https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Talk:WDFIST#E1:_Bad_API_response_mwoauth-invalid-authorization-invalid-user_despite_WiDaR_authorized.2C_on_Android) is fixed, I think we should also link to WDFIST like WikiShootMe does. For Wikidata items that do not have an image, it proposes some found on the Wikipedia articles linked to this item. Extremely useful before deciding whether walking that 2 kilometers detour is really worth it.

title: Tutorial again and quizz, for people who did not understand topicness/copyright immediately
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="gsoc 2018"), Label(name="question"), Label(name="user education")]
body:
Topicness and copyright are not innate, it can be hard to grasp what is OK and what is not (I am still struggling with it).
We can expect many users to not understand (or not even read) the first tutorial, but let's give these users another chance to learn before their account gets banned.

If a user gets more than 50% of reverts in their last 20 uploads (or other conditions), then show the tutorial slides again, followed by a quizz with questions about what is OK or not to upload. Examples:

(selfie picture)
OK to upload?    ✔ ✗

(picture of the Taj Mahal)
OK to upload?    ✔ ✗

(screenshot of The New York Times' mobile website)
OK to upload?    ✔ ✗

(blurry picture of a not-remarkable human hand)
OK to upload?    ✔ ✗

(picture of a Hmong wedding in traditional clothes)
OK to upload?    ✔ ✗

At every wrong answer, show an explanation.
At the end of the quizz: If more than 80% of good answers, unlock the app. If less, show the tutorial again then quizz again.

The quizz and tutorial could be adapted to what the user has not understood yet: topicness, copyright.
A variation could target people who enter extremely short titles and no description nor tags.

What do you think about this idea? I expect the idea of such "punishment" to be rather controversial.

title: Version and changelog for release
Update README with website and Google Play link
Improve data quality of Nearby List
body:
I was testing the improvements made in https://github.com/commons-app/apps-android-commons/issues/250 today using GPS spoofing. I was quite surprised how many items have question marks as icons. But the problem seems to be the data we use:

https://tools.wmflabs.org/wiki-needs-pictures/data/data.csv

The list classifies 3600 things as "adm3rd", which is probably a artefact of some vandalism? 150 000 items are undefined. That is 75 % of the 200 000 items in the list.

Another issue is that the list gives a string for the target-item of the p31 statement. I think it would be better to use the Q-ID both in the data and in the program code (Don't compare to the English label which could change over time).

Probably the easiest way of solving this would be to switch to a query.wikidata.org request. That returns the p31 statement along with some other information (e.g. the locale of the user to fetch the right labels). With the p31 target we can then assign the icons like this:

https://github.com/misaochan/apps-android-commons/blob/4b01f6e95f79cc507dba1ea0ff8335eef9b11521/app/src/main/java/fr/free/nrw/commons/nearby/NearbyListFragment.java#L192

```
switch(place.qid) {
                case "Q4022":
                    icon.setImageResource(R.drawable.icon_river;
                    break;
                case "Q355304":
                    icon.setImageResource(R.drawable.icon_river);
                    break;
```

Items:
- https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q4022
- https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q355304

Assigning the symbols is not trivial, but for a start we can just collect the most used items in p31 statements.
